scenes.location: BALL FIELD, OGDEN MARSH HIGH SCHOOL, KANSAS
characters: DEAD ON ONE SIDE, THE OTHER HALF IN VIOLENT SPASMS, MOUTH
THE FIRST HUNTER STANDS ON THE FRONT BUMPER, BEATING ON T
THE DASH LIGHTS ILLUMINATE AS THE DIESEL ENGINE ROARS TO
OBESE MAN IN SUSPENDERS LEANED INTENTLY OVER HIS BINGO CA
A LUMINOUS SHOCKWAVE RACING ACROSS THE PRAIRIE BEHIND THE
ALL THREE OF THEM ENTER THE RESTAURANT
A BIG-RIG CAB ELEVATED SIX FEET OFF THE GROUND ON A HYDRA
ARE PARALYZED ON ONE SIDE, RIDDLED WITH SPASMS ON THE OTH
A ROW OF MANNEQUINS IN FUNERAL SUITS AND SHOES
THE VERY CORNER WHERE DAVID AND JUDY ARE HIDING
A FIGURE IN A WHITE BIOHAZARD SUIT
DAVID, GET US OUT OF HERE
THE CAR WASH ROARS TO LIFE
PEOPLE ON GURNEYS GOING BERZERK. A TEENAGER RACKED BY WIL
IS THERE SOMEONE UNDER THE BED
THE COIN, TUMBLING THROUGH THE PAY PHONE AGAIN, FALL FROM
THE HUNTERS SHATTER THE WINDOW AND CLIMB INSIDE THE GARAG
TEETH-CLATTERING CONVULSIONS. OTHER PEOPLE SITTING IN
TELL HER TO SHUT HER MOUTH OR I'LL
JERKING BACK TO EXPOSE THE TEETH AND GUMS.
ALL THE PRISONERS RUN INTO THE WOODS LIKE LUNATICS FLEEIN
LIFELESS ARMS FLOP INTO FRAME. GREEN BARCODED BRACELETS O
AN OMINOUS METALLIC SCRAPING NOISE COMING DOWN THE DARK
SIDEWAYS AND GOES INTO A BARREL ROLL.
RETURN SLOT AND HIT THE FLOOR, FOLLOWED BY THE OMINOUS SO
WINDSHIELD WITH A TEN POUND STEEL WRENCH.
THE BLINDING WHITE DETONATION OF A NUCLEAR WARHEAD RIPS A
THE SUBURBAN HITS IT AT A HUNDRED MILES AN HOUR, SKIDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's DUSK. The DIN of night insects is all around. We're trudging along a rutted dirt road toward a glow on the horizon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball game being played under the lights behind the local high school. STUDENTS, FACULTY, TOWNSPEOPLE fill th wooden bleachers. It's the regional playoffs. Everybody i here. The MAYOR, the PASTOR, the FIRE CHIEF, all the VIPs small town has to offer. Even the town sheriff has turned up for the end of the ga He parks his cruiser in the overflow lot and comes down t hill to the diamond, keys jangling on his belt beside a holstered gun he never uses. DAVID DUTTON. Easy-going. Second-generation sheriff. Pillar of the community. Trading a dozen hellos, clapping some old timer on the shoulder, giving the coach a thumbs-up about the score, h comes around the backstop to the little CONCESSIONS TRAIL Sets his hat on the counter. Handsome. Grinning with hometown pride.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They're playin' well, Kev, they're playin' awful damn well. Win this one they could have a shot. (to Vendor's wife in b.g.) Hey Linda. She nods hi. The VENDOR pours him a cup of coffee, on the house.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: Fryeburg's tough. They'd be next.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (smile fades) Fryeburg, yeah. Shit. Well, one at a time, one at a time... David heads off, coffee in hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thanks, Kev. David leans on the sideline fence, sipping his coffee, watching the game. The star pitcher blows a fastball past the batter. David lets out a howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty McLeod! You throw like you drive, son, too damn fast! He puts down his coffee so he can applaud the strikeout w both hands then picks it up again and takes another sip.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look alive, fellas! Deano, watch the squeeze! No one has yet noticed the DARK FIGURE walking out of the shadowy woods beyond the outfield. Weaving like a drunkar he walks right onto the playing field, oblivious to the g Aman of fifty. Local pig farmer. His name is RORY HAMILL. He is carrying a SHOTGUN. Heads turn, mouths falling open in the bleachers and dugo everybody staring in collective disbelief. It's surreal, guy with a gun just walked past Petey Jenkins in left fie

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Rory, what in God -- ? David drops his coffee and jumps the fence, goes out acro the diamond to intercept him, hollering, waving his hands

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Rory, whoa, Rory, Rory, whoa, whoa, whoa! Rory Hamill gets as far as the infield before David, cutt in front of him now, keeping ten feet of distance, finall gets his attention.

dialogues.speaker: STOP I SAID
dialogues.text: Rory stops, glassy-eyed, head lolling sickly to one side. David keeps his gun holstered, tries to reason with him. players frozen at their positions on the field.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The hell you doing, Rore? Hunh? Got a ball game going on here. We're playing ball, you come out here with a gun? The goddamn hell you doing? Rory casts a glance around the field. A dizzying number o faces out there. All eyes on him. He wobbles a little, catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay it down, Rory, you're drunk. His gaze floats back to David and it's different than it a moment ago. Harder. Deadly. David is not a man easily spooked, but that look sends a chill right through him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Lay it down! Rory takes a wavering step forward. David draws his weapo Rory responds in kind, leveling his. People gasp. David retreats a step. Might be the first time in his life he's had a gun pointed at him by someone ready to use it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don't do it, Rory! Don't you do it! Rory brings his eye to the sights, draws back on the trig and - BANG! - David shoots first. A single shot, but a deadly one. Rory Hamill collapses midfield. SCREAMS from the bleachers and SOBS in the aftersilence a the whole town registers the strange human tragedy that j played out under the lights behind the high school. A body facedown in the grass behind the pitcher's mound, Sheriff David Dutton standing over it, astonished, holdin his hand the gun he never uses. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stillness of prairie grass in the blue hush before da Beyond it, a traditional white clapboard house with an ol barn that needs painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman awakens to find her husband's side of the b empty. Runs a hand over the sheet, checking for body warm It's cold. Strange. She puts on a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes downstairs in the darkened house.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Babe...? No reply. Worried, she comes down the hall into the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of him. She startles at a movement behind her. The SCREEN DOOR, creaking back and forth in a draft. She comes over to close it and sees, through the screen, husband sitting alone outside in the shadowy dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's David out here, second-guessing himself. His wife JU sits down quietly beside him, come to lend a sympathetic If he is one pillar of the community, she is the other, a local standout who came back from med school to be the to doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He didn’t give me a choice. Judy shakes her head in reassurance of that fact. Takes h hand for moral support. Looks to the distance, reflecting

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You asked me once when we first got together if I thought less of you for staying here after high school and following in your dad’s footsteps. I want you to know something. People like you, the ones that stay, are the reason why people like me come back. David meets her gaze, heartened by that, and then places hand gently, tellingly, on her midsection.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You should be sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's cruiser travels through the lonesome countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns in the drive of a rundown farmhouse on the outskirt town. Poorest family in Ogden Marsh. Parking, getting out David meets eyes with two boys feeding pigs behind the ba JAKE and CURT HAMILL. Rory's teenage sons. Tough kids, bu they've both been crying. Before David can say anything t turn coldly away. He goes up the front steps to the house. Takes off his h knocks. The door opens to reveal Rory's widow. PEGGY HAMILL. Awkward is an understatement. David is the last person she expected to see on her doorstep this morning.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Peggy, I... (sudden loss for words) I knew what I was gonna say before I got here... (then) I'm real sorry, Peg. I liked Rory, I liked him a lot. Whatever resentment she might have harbored is defused by David's simple decency. Looking him in the face, she just crumbles. It's heartbreaking.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY HAMILL
dialogues.text: (in heaving sobs) What was he doin'? What was he doin'? David holds her, the only thing keeping her upright. And see them from a distance, together in their anguish, the sheriff and the wife he made a widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone street light flashes yellow on Main Street. It wil do that all day. An A & P, a post office, a bank. No frills. No artifice. Like the people that live here. David's cruiser pulls up outside C. R. Finley Funeral Hom which doubles as the town morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORTICIAN CHARLES FINLEY and the TOWN PASTOR are discussi funeral arrangements in the dimly-lit foyer. David enters and they go silent, unintentionally.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pastor, Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PASTOR
dialogues.text: (to Finley in parting) I'll talk to the family, see if that schedule suits them. The Pastor pats David's arm as he exits, a gesture of solidarity. David comes over to Finley. An odd man whose bony features reflect the grim solitude of his trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medical examiner still here?

dialogues.speaker: FINLEY
dialogues.text: Was a minute ago.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Charlie, whatever the costs are for the funeral, bill comes to me, all right? Finley nods okay. David heads for the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIP OF A PEN writes: "Aorta ruptured - fatal wound: gunshot..." The MEDICAL EXAMINER, balding, bespectacled, finishing hi autopsy notes. David walks over. A body sheeted in plasti on the autopsy table. Tag on the toe: HAMILL, RORY C.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just wanted to get his blood- alcohol, put in my report.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Zero-point-zero.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Zero-point—-

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I heard what you said. Stacy, that's not right, he was drunk. The Examiner shakes his head. Collects his things to go.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Checked it twice. Rory was a drinker, but not last night. He exits. David, baffled, peels back the sheet and studie the corpse like it might offer clues. But there is only t grim reality of death. The tell-tale Y-shaped incision sutured shut across the torso. And the small black hole his bullet made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, functional. David's lone deputy is fielding phone calls in the common area. DEPUTY RUSSELL. Young. Capable. Built like a linebacker. He'd be sheriff if David weren't around but his loyalty is absolute.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (into phone) I can’t answer that - look, like I said, you'll have to talk to Sheriff Dutton, try back later. David enters as he hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russ. David goes into his office. Sorts through the mail on his desk. Russell follows, only as far as the doorway, stands there for a moment gauging the climate.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Some fuckin' ball game, huh. David sits down, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humble brick building with a sign out front. Home of the wildcats.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So you all saw something last night I sure wish you hadn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, before a microphone, addressing the STUDENTS in general assembly. SCHOOL OFFICIALS looking on.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ..-Hard to make sense of it, even for me. Talk to your teachers, talk to me if you want... The SEA OF YOUNG FACES, some visibly upset, some visibly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..--We don’t have all the answers, but we’re here to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post assembly, David walks down the hall with the PRINCIP Students swarm past back to class. Flirting. Talking on cell phones. Life returning to normal.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Wasn't so long ago you were roaming these halls. That hellraiser turned into a sheriff somehow. And a fine one. (then) Your mom and dad still liking Florida okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dad swore he wouldn't last a month down there. Then he saw the golf courses. They come past a teacher who can’t unlock his classroom d Mid-forties. Shirt and tie. Native Kansan. BILL FARNUM.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Bill...?

dialogues.speaker: BILL FARNUM
dialogues.text: I give up. They rekey the locks this weekend? Maybe it’s jammed... Farnum tugs on the door, mystified. But no one is more mystified than David and the Principal.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Bill, you don’t - you retired, five years ago. Farnum looks at them in utter confusion. Rubs his nose an his finger comes back with a BLOODY SMUDGE on it. The Principal offers a handkerchief as he walks Farnum away, gesturing to David ‘I got it’.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Hit your head or something? Come on, why don’t you sit down in my office. David watches them go, the tide of students flowing past

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stands at the fence staring at the empty field, dismayed. TWO PLANES fly past high overhead. Side by side a half mi apart. David glances up, barely taking notice. Sees the coffee c he dropped is still lying there in the grass. Tosses it i the trash can before heading up the hill to his cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're flying over the prairie at ten thousand feet. Beautiful view. Farms. Open fields. A sudden burst of HIG SPEED PHOTOGRAPHS rips the entire county into a GRID OF FREEZE FRAMES. EXT. TOWN CENTER —- SUNDOWN Small town life. Families in the local pizza joint. Guy washing his truck. Woman walking her dog on an empty road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single-story brick-and-mortar building with two cars in lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, in a traditional white doctor's coat, gives a tetan shot to a boy with a bandaged foot. She has a gentle touc

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (finished) Wasn’t too bad, was it? The boy shakes his head. He and his mother stand to go.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (musses boy's hair) Adventure on, young man, but keep an eye out for...?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Rusty nails.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Rusty nails. (to mother) Take care, Dana. Let me know if there’s any swelling.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical slow night. Judy is updating records with her par time office helper BECCA DARLING. Seventeen. Pretty. Loca honor student. NURSE VIOLET, town gossip, also the clinic receptionist, wanders over, bored, buffing her nails.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE VIOLET
dialogues.text: Started talking about names yet?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE VIOLET
dialogues.text: If it’s a girl, I like Beatrice. If it’s a boy, Morton. Knew a Morton once, ‘course we all called him Morty, maybe you should just go with Morty.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (endearing, not poking fun) Thanks, Violet, I'll put those on the list. Becca’s cell phone CHIRPS. She checks the message, keys i quick reply and resumes work, the entire exchange lasting seconds.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Okay if I leave a little early tonight? Judy, playing, scans the empty waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Hmmm, how’s our staff to patient ratio? I think you’re good. Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Yeah. Casey Strout’s having some people over.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Algebra?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Yep. Math party.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: My husband excelled at math in high school.  11. Becca smiles. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, he was really cool at assembly today.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: It’s so scary to think what would've happened if he hadn’t been there the other night. Judy nods her agreement.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Sometimes you just get lucky like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIANT WET TONGUES licking something, licking each other i the process. A disturbing image, but only in close-up... DAIRY COWS at a salt lick. Bill Farnum stands in the corral watching, ankle deep in briefcase in hand, blank expression. His wife DEARDRA cal to him from the house porch in the b.g., twelve-year-old NICHOLAS under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: William! If he hears her, he gives no visible indication. Nicholas jogs down to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: Supper’s ready. Farnum stands motionless, mesmerized. Nicholas starts to climb the fence and suddenly his father speaks, without looking, as though he was listening all along:

dialogues.speaker: BILL FARNUM
dialogues.text: Be in in a sec. Nicholas heads back to the house. Bill Farnum picks his w across the muddy pen to the salt lick. Surrounded by mooi cows, he stares at it -- brick-shaped, pinkish white, dripping with bovine saliva -- then bends and gives it a disgusting lick.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crescent moon. David eyeing it from the back porch as he drinks a beer in his unbuttoned sheriff's shirt. Judy enters the kitchen behind him. Weary from the day. Sees him through the door. He holds her gaze for a moment then puts his hand under his shirt and gives it a little flutter, meaning his heart still beats for her. Makes her smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss by the old gas stove. He brushes a lock of stra hair from her face. Married his dream.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hungry? (she nods) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (isn't sure) Omelet?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: Judy at the table eating her omelet. David sitting opposi polishing her wedding band on his shirt. A ritual of his.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Could drive you up to see your parents this weekend, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Penance for your sins? He smiles a little, slips the ring back on her finger, restored to its original luster. Then, still troubled by day’s events:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thought maybe the moon was full, I don’t know, definitely some weirdness going around. Medical examiner said he found nothing in Rory’s system.  13.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Meaning - ?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Meaning, according to the state, the man I shot was sober.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What did Peggy say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Saw him at lunch and he seemed fine. A mystery. David left with only his instincts. And the memory:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Looked him right in the eye. He was under the influence of something. If it wasn’t alcohol it was something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cows moo behind the barn. It's after midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drift through the dark hundred-year-old house, past th stairs, down the hall into the kitchen, past an old pot- bellied woodstove to the sink where we find Deardra in a nightgown looking out the window. Worried. Nicholas enter in pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: Pa come in yet? Deardra shakes her head no. Her eyes never leave the wind Nicholas comes over, sees what she's staring at.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: What's he doin’? Off in the distance, a COMBINE is going around in circles a field, its spotlights sweeping the prairie like a lighthouse beacon. Deardra takes a flashlight from the top of the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: Wait here.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: House in the b.g., Deardra crosses the field, spotlights whipping across her face. Lit up like a nebula against the night sky, the billowing dust cloud gives the combine an otherworldly aura. A kill machine circling for prey, the thresher a gaping mouth of giant spinning teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up close, the noise is deafening. Deardra strides into range. Cups her hands to her mouth and calls up to the darkened cab.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: William...?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield we can see her out there calling t us, disappearing from view as the combine goes around aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deardra calls once more then jogs over and climbs the met rungs to the cab. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: William Blaine Farnum, what in heaven's -- EMPTY SEAT. A haunted pause then Deardra slides in behind the wheel. Powers down the engine. Turns off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big machine grinds to a halt and there's a hush. Dear climbs down. Scans the dark, windswept fields.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: William...? Her voice carries without answer. She turns on the flashlight and walks out into the field.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: The swaying wheat. The pulse of cicadas. And then, from back at the house, a BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM. Her son.  15.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: Oh God... Deardra takes off running for the house. Frantic. Elbows flying.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: Another SCREAM. Deardra, in full flight, screams back.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: She crosses the field at a dead sprint. And hears somethi worse than a scream as she reaches the house. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs up the steps. In the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slows as she comes down the dark hallway. No sign of son. No sign of her husband.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: Nicholas...? Silence. At the top of the stairs - A HANGING BULB SWINGS like a pendulum, casting eerie shif shadows. Deardra looks up the stairs at it. No sane perso would go up there, except a mother for a child. She climbs the stairs. Slowly, one step at a time. The ol boards CREAKING underfoot. The bulb’s shadows rocking bac and forth across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Topping the stairs, she comes down the hall. Eyes wide wi fear. Shadows dancing. The light is on in the BATHROOM. Door closed. Deardra reaches out a hand, pushes the door slowly open -- CREEEEEAK -- and sees...

dialogues.speaker: EMPTY BATHROOM
dialogues.text: She looks down the hall. Darkness at the other end. Voice trembling, she calls into it.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: Nicholas...?  16. As she takes her next step SOMEONE GRABS HER FROM BEHIND, throws a hand over her mouth and pulls her into the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas. Terrified. He gestures for silence, takes his hand from Deardra's mouth. Their pale faces lit by the li coming through the crack.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: What happened? What did he do? Nicholas, answer me.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: He has a knife. A chill runs through Deardra.

dialogues.speaker: DEARDRA
dialogues.text: (re: closet) We can't stay here. She cracks the door, peers out. Just then, a terrible sou FOOTSTEPS coming heavily up the stairs. And now they have no choice but the closet. Nicholas shut the door and grips the handle with both hands, praying he strong enough to keep his father out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Farnum climbs the stairs into view. He is holding a KNIFE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deardra helps Nicholas hold the door as Bill’s FOOTSTEPS pounding down the hallway to the closet where they STOP ABRUPTLY. Five seconds that feel like forever as Deardra and Nichol listen to Bill's HOLLOW BREATHS on the other side of the door. Both clutching the door handle, expecting it to get ripped open any second. Instead we hear a KEY go into the lock and turn - CLICK. FOOTSTEPS head back downstairs. Nicholas tries the handle couple of times before turning gravely to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: He locked us in.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slinging gasoline everywhere, Farnum walks out the front door. Empties what's left in the five-gallon can onto the porch and lights it with a match. He sits down in the yard and watches it burn. Devoid of emotion. The house his grandfather built. His wife and so SCREAMING from within as blue flames scurry up the inside walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RINGING PHONE wakes up David and Judy. They both reach it. His hand gets there first.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dutton... He sits bolt upright, registering the news.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm coming. Jumps out of bed. Judy does the same before she even know why.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Farnums’, the whole place is going up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engulfed. VOLUNTEER FIREMEN hose down the trees, too late save the house or anyone inside. David's cruiser pulls up He and Judy push through the crowd of onlookers to the FI CHIEF.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Norman, did they get out?! The Fire Chief shakes his head. Judy, horrified, eyes the inferno that used to be a farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: Bill did. Begs the question, doesn't it? David takes his meaning. Crosses to where Bill Farnum sit on the back bumper of a firetruck, expressionless, hands with baling twine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What happened, Bill?  18. Farnum doesn't respond. David squats in front of him, getting in his eyeline.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bill, what happened here tonight? Farnum meets his gaze, glassy-eyed, remorseless.

dialogues.speaker: BILL FARNUM
dialogues.text: A reckoning. Madness. David staring it in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The burning house from ten thousand feet. Tiny, almost beautiful. Fire engines flashing around it like a child’s toys. A burst of FREEZE-FRAMES. The camera ZOOMS IN TIGHT Another burst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning, Russell is outside trying to placate some L REPORTERS as David talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Was hoping to transfer him, we’re not really equipped for this sort of thing. Okay, two o'clock. Hangs up. A haunted pause. The last forty-eight hours betraying everything he knows. He turns his gaze to Bill Farnum who sits in a stupor in a holding cell at the back the station. Russell enters.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: They tell me they don't want the deputy, they want the sheriff. David gets up from his desk. Still watching Farnum.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Looked at me last night like he coulda slit my throat and barely known the difference. (turns to Russell) Same look Rory gave me. Same goddamn look. Walks out to talk to the press.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plumes of smoke rise from the ashes. A scorched brick chimney stands like a monument to the dead. David picks u charred photo. The Farnum family. He drops it, surveys th scene with dismay. A faint DRONING HUM draws his gaze skyward. Those SAME TW PLANES flying over. Side by side a half mile apart. But lower this time. David's eyes narrow with suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What're you lookin' for? And as the search planes dip below the far treeline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freshwater marsh on the outskirts, the town's namesake. OLD TIMER in hipwaders is dumping crayfish from wire trap into a bucket. He hears something. Straightens for a look Twenty yards away, something white is billowing like an untrimmed mainsail. He comes over for a look. Touches the material. Ripstop nylon. Billowing again, it's clear what it is... A PARACHUTE. He follows the twisted cords over a rise in the marsh to where they settle in deeper water beyond. Gives the lines tug and then staggers backwards in horror as - A HUMAN BODY floats to the surface. Hideously discolored. Bloated from decomposition.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TIMER
dialogues.text: Lord God... A MILITARY PILOT. Oxygen mask on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bodybag zipper opens to reveal the pilot's ROTTING CORP David catches a glimpse and turns away, he's seen enough. Russell gags at the stench. Even Finley, mortician of twe years, looks a little grossed out.

dialogues.speaker: FINLEY
dialogues.text: I'll see if there's any identification.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (exits; needing air) Yeah, do that.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Russell cough the stench from their lungs as th cross the parking lot. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Got us a pilot, where's the plane? Russell, as they reach the cruiser, recollects:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Travis King - you know Travis?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know he's a lyin' bastard.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Said he heard something out by Hopman Bog last week. I thought he was tellin' stories again. David slows, meets Russell's gaze over the roof of the cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, Russell and TRAVIS KING, a human rodent, motoring across the bog in a flat-bottomed aluminum boat.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Sounded like a plane you said, huh, Trav?

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS KING
dialogues.text: Yep. I gettin' paid for this?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Big plane, little plane?

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS KING
dialogues.text: I dunno, a plane, I was on the shitter. So how much I gettin'?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Travis.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS KING
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say that again you'll be the second person I shot this week.  21. Travis takes him at his word. David notices something up ahead. Turns the boat toward it for a better look.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Whaddaya see, chief? David indicates a spot in the woods where the tops of tre have been sheared off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Something came real close to taking a bath. David kills the outboard and they drift in closer. A stra toxic sheen to the water in this area. Russell reaches tw fingers down for a sample. David yanks Russell's hand bac

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Then don't touch it. David bends for a closer look. The spill has that chemica rainbow quality of gasoline. Jettisoned fuel perhaps. He scoops some into a Mason jar. Pauses as he screws on the lid.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It was a big plane.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Why's that? David straightens, oddly quiet, staring at the water.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Cause we're right on top of it. Off Russell's look, we rise up above them, to the height the treetops, and see what David sees - THE MURKY CONTOUR OF A MILITARY TRANSPORT PLANE submerged the water where it crashed, the boat floating directly ab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David talks on a cell phone while he and Russell unhook t boat trailer outside the corrugated-steel equipment shed.  22.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (into phone) Say, you folks missing a plane? (brow furrows) No? Well somebody oughta tell that to the pilot in our morgue. Military, yes, ma'am. Dutton. D-U- T-T-O-N. Yep, I'll be here. He pockets the phone. Stews.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Plane that size goes down and there's nothing in the paper, nothing on the news? Make any sense to you? Russell shrugs, unlocking the shed.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Depends what the payload is. It's an off-hand remark, means more to David than Russell He looks at the MASON JAR of tainted water on the hood of truck then turns a brooding stare to the north, a pattern thought taking shape.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hopman Bog, what's that drain into?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Dwyer Creek.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Which drains into...?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Black Pond. Hey, you remember that monster catfish I --

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (turns) Black Pond? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yeah... Russell isn't following yet.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russ, where the hell you think we get our water from?  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOPOGRAPHICAL MAP of the county on the wall. The Ogden Ma watershed shaded in blue. David barges in, asking his question on the fly. The TOWN PLANNER is eating lunch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Which way's the water flow through town?

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PLANNER
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, too, Dave. Waste water or drinking?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Drinking. Town Planner unfolds a chart. A SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM OF THE TOWN'S WATER SYSTEM, his finger tracing the main pipeline

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PLANNER
dialogues.text: Comes in from the north, breaks east west...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whose house does it get to first?

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PLANNER
dialogues.text: Most outlying. Let's see, uh... Runs his finger along a certain outlying route to a certa outlying farm. Looks up at David.

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PLANNER
dialogues.text: Rory Hamill. Hold on David's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With discreet alarm David shows Judy the water system schematic at the reception desk. Points to the second mos outlying farm.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Next house is Bill Farnum's. I mean, am I talking nonsense here or is it possible they reacted to something they drank, something in the water?  24.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: If it's contaminated, if the concentration's high enough - but, David, we're drinking that same water. Everybody is. If there's something in it, we're all going to get it. David backs away, crisis on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Farnum's are a mile out, might not have made it this far yet. Tell everybody don't drink it. He runs out. Judy - the schematic in CLOSEUP - runs her finger from 'FARNUM DAIRY' across town to the pipeline's five miles from Black Pond, a plot labelled 'DUTTON FARM' She contemplates that distance, their safety buffer, then raises her gaze to the WAITING ROOM. It’s half full. There is a WOMAN sitting head slumped forward in the corner chair. Judy walks over, look of concern. Lifts the woman’s chin. The widow, Peggy Hamill, unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Peggy? Can you hear me? Peg...? Peggy's eyes flutter open partway. Pupils dilated. Barely conscious.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You need to lay down? Peggy ATTACKS without warning. Knocks Judy off her feet, tearing her blouse. It takes three guys to pull her off a subdue her as Nurse Violet helps a badly shaken Judy to h feet.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE VIOLET
dialogues.text: What’s gotten into her? Peggy Hamill, held down, writhing and shrieking on the fl EXT. POOL, MAYOR’S HOUSE - DAY A flabby white-bread bureaucrat saunters up the steps of in-ground pool, toweling off after a morning swim. MAYOR HOBBS.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: That water's contaminated I’m Hilary goddamn Clinton.  25. David puts the jar of toxic water in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm shutting it down, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: (eyeing jar then pool) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MUNICIPAL WORKER muscles the wheelcrank on a high-press pipe valve, shutting off the town's water. Done, he looks at David from the hole he's in.

dialogues.speaker: MUNICIPAL WORKER
dialogues.text: off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, driving back into town, lost in thought, RADIO PLAYING.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: WKLC Kansas City. News on the hour every hour. Fire crews in Southern California continue to battle wildfires this morning -- The signal goes to STATIC. David gives the radio a glance. Tries a different station STATIC. Flips through all the stations - STATIC. Weird. And then something weirder. Out of the corner of his eye, barely seen in the blur of a passing field. Whoosh -

dialogues.speaker: A FIGURE IN A WHITE BIOHAZARD SUIT
dialogues.text: So incongruous it takes a moment to register. What the he He slams on the brakes. Backs up, craning his neck to see what he saw. Can't see it from here. Stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gets out and comes around the cruiser. Surveys the field. Nothing there. Nothing but prairie. David stares across i haunted, the radio in the cruiser HISSING STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters, dazed.  26.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Either I'm losin' it completely or I just saw a guy in a spacesuit out by Hadley Road. Russell gestures over to his shoulder to the holding cell

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: That makes two guys losin' it. Bill Farnum is going BERSERK back there. Smashing his hea against the wall. Tearing the cell apart. Uncontrollable rage. David, awed, steps to the windowed partition and watches. Farnum turns. His face is hideous. ONE SIDE PARALYZED LIK A STROKE VICTIM, THE OTHER IN VIOLENT SPASMS. He hurls himself at the glass - WHAM! - almost shatters it. David steps back as he goes berserk again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did we or did we not request a transfer to Wichita this morning? Rhetorical question. He picks up the phone. Starts to dia Toggles the receiver. Line's dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yup. Russell tosses him a cell phone. David hits the first two digits then sees the viewscreen - "SEARCHING FOR SIGNAL.. tosses it back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Even better. Russell frowns and steps outside, trying to get a connect David tries the tv. WHITE NOISE. Turns it off. Clicks the computer mouse. CANNOT FIND SERVER. Tries the police scanner. STATIC. Switches it off, smiling at the improbability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell meantime can't get a signal. David steps out besi him, surveys the town from the top of the steps. His face black with foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know what...

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What?  27.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREECH. David's cruiser brakes to a halt at town center. He gets out. Scans Main Street. An ominous calm. The SQUEAKING of a bicycle chain turns his head. A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN pedaling toward him on a girl's pink- tasseled banana-seat bike, singing in eerie falsetto, an hymnal.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN ON BIKE
dialogues.text: .--All things bright and beautiful, all creatures great and small, all things wise and wonderful, The Lord God made them all... She rides past David, lost in her own world, her haunting song filling the silence. ALTERNATE POV (through SLR camera) - From a block away, a BURST OF PHOTOGRAPHS captures the woman on the bicycle, t panning to David, a second BURST captures him as he cross Main Street, still watching the woman. As the photos continue snapping, he slowly turns, sensing he's being watched, and looks straight into camera...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Tight on David's face as he stands in the center of Main Street, staring at: A BLACK CHEVY SUBURBAN WITH TINTED WINDOWS idling at the corner by the bank. Not a car that belongs to Ogden Marsh David approaches, hand drifting instinctively toward his It tears off down the road. Fantastic acceleration. David stares for a moment, baffled. As he dashes back to his cruiser to give pursuit, a panicked WOMAN jogs across the street from the pizza shop.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Sheriff, we heard something from the funeral home little while ago.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What'd you hear?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Screamin'.  28. A frozen moment. David turns his gaze to the funeral home the street. Grabs his CB handset from the cruiser. Brings it to his mouth and clicks the button. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Lizzie, run down the station, tell Russell what you just told me, tell him I need him asap. She takes off running as David heads up the street to the funeral home, unholstering his weapon for the second time three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closed for business. David tries the front door. Locked. He goes around the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the bodies are brought in. David enters, nervous, g drawn. He stops and faces -

dialogues.speaker: A WHITE TILED CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sterile. Eerily silent. A few gurneys and unopened boxes odorless body bags and cotton shrouds in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Charlie? No reply. David comes slowly along, white-knuckled grip o his gun. The hall is lined on both sides with closed door David comes to a door, turns the knob, opens it to reveal

dialogues.speaker: THE EMBALMING ROOM
dialogues.text: Stainless steel embalming tables. Sinks. Sluices. Rinse hoses dangling from the ceiling. No bodies. No Finley. David continues down the hall. Comes through a door into the front of the shop. The FUNE HOME. Pink-hued walls. Liver-colored carpet. David pushes open another door.

dialogues.speaker: A ROOM OF CASKETS
dialogues.text: darkly polished. On display. David steps in, scans the room. All the caskets are open except THAT ONE. He crosses to it. With a silent two-count throws open the lid and takes aim at  29.

dialogues.speaker: A SILKY WHITE PILLOW
dialogues.text: Empty casket. David closes it. To his immediate left -

dialogues.speaker: A CURTAINED ALCOVE
dialogues.text: runs the length of the wall. Coming past it to the door, David suddenly steps back and levels his gun.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE IS HIDING
dialogues.text: behind that curtain. The tips of his shoes poking out underneath.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Charlie? No reply. But there’s definitely a man in black shoes standing there. David steps closer. Takes hold of the curtain. Whisks it open to reveal -

dialogues.speaker: A ROW OF MANNEQUINS IN FUNERAL SUITS AND SHOES
dialogues.text: David almost puts a bullet in one. Curses under his breat Suddenly hears something. Very faint. Coming from behind him. Down the white-tiled hall he just exited... Is someone WEEPING? David cocks the hammer of his gun. Follows that FAINT MUFFLED WEEPING down the hall to a closed door. Opens it.

dialogues.speaker: THE MORGUE
dialogues.text: No sign of Finley. Just sheet-covered CORPSES on autopsy tables. The weeping HAS STOPPED. David enters. Autopsy scales hang beside the bodies. Closets and refrigerated shelves along the walls. David yanks open a closet door, gun trained, expecting to find Finley. Nothing but medical supplies. A faint WHIMPER turns his head. He stares at the FIVE COVERED BODIES.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Charlie, if that's you, say something! No reply. Gun in hand, he steps closer to the bodies. Pee back the covers one by one:  30. RORY HAMILL'S CHALK WHITE CORPSE. THE DECOMPOSING PILOT. DEARDRA FARNUM'S CHARRED CORPSE. HER SON'S. David stares at the LAST COVERED BODY. We can see the outline of a face. The sheet expands and contracts at the nostrils. Slightly. As if from breath.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Charlie? No answer. Gun levelled, David takes the edge of the shee whisks it back to find -

dialogues.speaker: THE TOWN PASTOR
dialogues.text: Weeping through sutured eyelids. The sutures on one eye h loosened, a ghastly eye peers out through the slit. His nostrils and lips are sewn shut, arms and legs bound to t table with gauze.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jim - ?! The Pastor goes into violent CONVULSIONS. David grabs a p of surgical scissors from a tray and, pinning the writhin body with one hand, cuts the sutures sealing the mouth. The Pastor's lips come apart like a deep fleshy wound, hi convulsions subsiding only because death is imminent. In last tortured breath:

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PASTOR
dialogues.text: Behind... you... What? David turns. WHIRRRR!! - THE BLADE OF A BONE SAW coming right at his f Finley swinging it at arm's length with psychotic calm. David goes down and Finley pounces, driving the blade at throat. David catches Finley's wrists, barely keeping the saw at bay, forces the spinning blade against the leg of autopsy table. SPARKS FLY as it cuts into the steel. Finley counters. Finding his knees, he brings the saw abo his head for a final plunge. But David catches him with a thrusting kick to the gut. Sends Finley crashing into the storage cabinets.  31. As he jumps up for more - BANG! - David shoots him. Finle falls in a heap. But in death he has launched perhaps his most lethal attack, dropping the SAW. Locked in the 'on' position, it COMES SKIP-BOUNCING ACROS THE FLOOR AT DAVID, propelled by the spinning blade. Davi scrambles backwards on his haunches, but can't outrun it. Just as it's about to hit him in the face -

dialogues.speaker: A BOOT
dialogues.text: stomps on the saw's cord, leashing it like a wild dog. Th deadly instrument hops and skips around at the end of its tether, inches from David's face. Until - Russell, owner of the boot, yanks the plug from the wall. comes over, helps David to his feet. And only then sees t Pastor's sad fate.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Christ almighty. A DEAD EYE staring back at them through the sutured slit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency town meeting. Worried TOWNSFOLK abound. David a Judy trying to manage everyone's fear and anger.

dialogues.speaker: CONCERNED MOTHER
dialogues.text: What are we supposed to drink while the water’s turned off?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The A & P has plenty of bottled. Bruce’s agreed to sell it at cost till we work out another source. Thanks again, Bruce. The A & P Manager nods.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: And it just so happens while all this is going on none of the phones are working?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know, Nathan. Russell’s on his way to Wichita right now, see if we can get some answers.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Where the hell's Mayor Hobbs?  32.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: Hightailin' it to Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (shock and disgust) What - ?

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: Saw him on the way out of town. Fat bastard practically ran me over. The kid’s mom swats him for talking like that. David and Judy exchanging a look about Hobbs. De facto town leaders

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FARMER
dialogues.text: So whoever drank it's gonna go the way of Rory and Bill? I drank it. My wife drank it. My kids.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We don't know that it's going to affect everybody the same, everybody's body reacts a little diff -- EERIE LAUGHTER cuts her off. A woman in the back. Horn- rimmed glasses. Ten-dollar wig. Going red in the face she laughing so hard. It's creepy, she can't stop. Everybody just stares as this demented old lady laughs and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheriff department PICKUP speeds down the fog-cloaked highway toward Wichita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell humming along at eighty miles an hour. Checks his radio. STATIC. Turns it off. Suddenly, FOUR DEAFENING POP

dialogues.speaker: -- ALL FOUR TIRES BLOW OUT
dialogues.text: A SPIKE STRIP lying across the road. The truck fishtails of control, wobbling violently on its rims, threatening t roll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell struggles, teeth-clenched, not to let it.  33.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Shit! Ruptured treads fly off. The pickup careens off the shoul and slams to a stop in an irrigation ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell has barely righted himself when he’s pulled from truck by a DOZEN SOLDIERS IN BIOHAZARD SUITS. Thrown against the hood, M-16s in his face, Russell’s astonishme is almost comical.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile David and Judy. Tense words in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Maybe you should go stay with your parents for a while.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Maybe you should go stay with my parents.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look, this isn't --

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No, David, you're not the only one with responsibilities here, half these people are my -- Sees something out the kitchen window. It scares her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What? What was it?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (isn't sure) Shadow. David grabs his gun and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stands at the edge of the property, eyeing the back field. It's eerily still.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Somebody there?!  34. Silence. Turning, he sees the light is on inside the

dialogues.speaker: GARDEN SHED
dialogues.text: He walks over, pushes open the door with the gun muzzle. he peeks warily inside -- LAWN TOOLS CLATTER NOISILY to the floor. Scares the hell out him. David switches off the light and then hears GLAS SHATTER inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who are you?! Who are you?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He crosses the yard at a sprint, kicks open the screen do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sees THREE SOLDIERS IN BIOHAZARD SUITS forcibly escor Judy to the front door. David lunges into the fray, gun outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What the fu--?! Get off her!! His heroics are short-lived. Grabbed, spun, put ina chokehold, he is disarmed and dragged out the door by the suited intruders. It's over in two seconds flat - chillin the ease with which he is subdued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wrestle Judy aboard an idling SCHOOL BUS. David behi her, still resisting, choked blue in the face.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where are you taking us?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurtling along under armed guard, David and Judy see shoc images out the windows. FAMILIES BEING PULLED FROM EVERY HOUSE IN SIGHT. The entire town being corralled onto buse like pigs off to slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL THE TOWNSPEOPLE stand in lines under the lights. Stunned. No one saw this coming. Raised ten feet and topp with razor wire, the fence is patrolled by armed guards i hazmat suits. A recorded message plays over the field's tinny P.A. system:  35.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: ...Please remain calm and do not interfere with the work of the examiners. Information will be provided to you as it becomes available. Thank you for your cooperation... Repeating ad infinitum as BIOSUITED EXAMINERS come down t lines with digital ear thermometers checking temperatures single BEEP means you're okay. A quick triple BEEP-BEEP-B means you're not and prompts a swift response, which we s playing out across the field: Burly MEDTECHS loading the unlucky person into one of the many golf carts on the scene - pulling wives away from husbands, husbands away from wives, children from parents parents from children - a coldly scientific process that with the golf carts speeding the outtakes up the hill to high school while loved ones scream in vain for their ret Here are David and Judy, as stunned and disoriented as everyone else. David confronts a passing examiner, his outrage reflected back at him in the mirrored faceshield.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What did we get exposed to?! What was it?! The examiner walks past without reply. Judy meanwhile appraises the medical teams, the work being done.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Elevated temperature usually means infection, but a toxin can do the same thing... I don't know, the way Peggy was acting makes me think it's chemical.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So they round us up with assault rifles, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Medical response teams train with case studies, they know the symptomology, pharmacological outcomes --—

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In plainspeak.  36.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (looks at him) They're as scared as we are. Judy steps away to help an ASTHMATIC ELDERLY WOMAN who is leaning against the fence. Soldiers escort MAYOR HOBBS an his WIFE onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: Governor Hatfield's a personal friend of mine! Nobody cares. They get dumped in a line near David. Hobbs draws hostile stares. Word of his hasty exodus has apparently gotten around.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey Tom, how's Kentucky?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: Bastards spiked our tires, pulled us out at gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wow, sounds like your civil rights might have been violated, you should look into that. Hobbs frowns at the sarcasm, taking in the angry stares.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: (re: Kentucky) Is that what everybody's so ticked off at me for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You ran. Town needed a leader.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR HOBBS
dialogues.text: You be the leader.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's not our town anymore. David steps to the fence, watches the guards prowling the perimeter. Otherworldly riflemen with biohazard hoods and leashed dogs. His gaze finds the old scoreboard behind th backstop. Lingers on it. Something poignant about it ther behind the barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: HOME OF THE WILDCATS
dialogues.text: But what he sees past it is chilling. Two figures standin in the tungsten glow of a flood light, staring at him...  37.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE AND CURT HAMILL
dialogues.text: Rory's sons. Delirious with rage and vengeance. THEIR FAC

dialogues.speaker: ARE PARALYZED ON ONE SIDE, RIDDLED WITH SPASMS ON THE OTH
dialogues.text: Teeth and gums exposed by some obscene tightening of the muscles. A LOUD DULCET TONE on the PA system makes David jump. He looks back and the Hamill boys are gone. Haunted, he scan the dark woods. And suddenly - A HAND grabs his shoulder. He spins, ready for a fight. It’s his deputy.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Funny thing happened on the way to Wichita. Gallows humor. Followed by a deadly serious:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Who are these fuckers?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Same ones who don’t know anything about a dead pilot and aren't missing a plane. David surveys the crowd, sensing beneath the fear and bewilderment a growing rage. It’s palpable, a chemical sh in their psychology.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: This don’t end well. David shakes his head - nope. An EXAMINER comes down the line checking temperatures. David engages.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I need to talk to somebody right now! Hey, do you hear me?! The examiner jams a thermometer in David’s ear. Pushes th button. BEEP. Moves on to Judy, who is preoccupied with patient care.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This woman is asthmatic, she needs her medica --

dialogues.speaker: BEEP-BEEP-BEEP
dialogues.text: Time stands still. Judy in disbelief. David spins to fend off the onrushing medtechs.  38.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Get away from her! She’s not sick, she’s pregnant! They grab her. David fights, but is hopelessly outnumbere Russell tries to help and is quickly subdued. They drag J away screaming.

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE HER ALONE
dialogues.text: You've never seen a man fight like David Dutton fights fo his wife. Zapped with a Tazer gun, kicked, knocked to the ground by a rifle butt, kicked once more. Again and again tries to rise, again and again he is beaten down, until h body no longer answers to his will. Lying in the grass, he lifts his gaze just enough to see being taken up the hill to the high school. By sheer stubbornness, he climbs to his feet once more. Takes a couple of wobbly steps. A gun butt CRACKS him in the back of the head. He goes do and stays there this time. Facedown in the dirt by second base. Expelling one last breath of resistance, her name along with it:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Judy... And then, mercifully, he blacks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV of ceiling lights whipping by above as a masked exami wheels us down the corridor. It's Judy’s POV, strapped to a gurney. The passing classrooms offer flashes of nightmare imagery:

dialogues.speaker: STUPORS, DROOLING.
dialogues.text: Suddenly, right in front of us - A SCREAMING FACE SHATTERS the window of a classroom door, spraying the corridor with shards that CRUNCH as we roll them. A biosuited GUARD beats the screaming man back with baton. Turning the corner, we see  39.

dialogues.speaker: THE GYMNASIUM
dialogues.text: Spanned by rows of sterile-white cots that have not been touched. Unopened boxes of supplies on pallets. Equipment wrapped in plastic. A medical contingency plan abandoned its early stages. As Judy is pushed into a maintenance elevator, an EXAMINE leans over her with an ANESTHESIA MASK. She tries to resi but her arms are strapped and the mask fitted so quickly her face that her scream of protest fogs the plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David awakens in darkness. Lifts his head, disoriented. He’s lying in what appears to be a livestock trailer. Judy. The thought sends him scrambling to the back door. rams it with his shoulder. Pounds it with his fists. Kick it with his boot. His fists again. And as he continues th futile effort to force it open - A DARK FIGURE emerges from the shadows behind him. Creepi closer. Aman. Sinister face catching the light. David, still hammering the door, doesn't see him coming. The figure stops right behind David and we see the grim visage was a trick of the shadows. It's his friend, the concessions vendor from the ball game. KEVIN MILLER.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: David... David spins, wild-eyed, caught in a moment of madness.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Kevin! I gotta get outta here! Continues his furious pounding.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (spins again)

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: You're scaring us. David sees them now. FACES IN SHADOW at the far end, terrified by his erratic behavior. Men, women, children. Faces we recognize from the ball game, the high school, t town meeting. David calms himself, explaining:  40.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They took Judy.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: (commiserates ) They took Linda. (indicating other unmatched spouses) And they took George and Francine and Whit and Simon and a whole mess of other people. Breaking your hand on that door's still a dumb idea. David takes his point. Follows Miller back to the group. The townspeople sit huddled together like Third World refugees. A mechanic in a John Deere ball cap (EDWARD) engages David. Frazzled nerves fuel the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Can't you do something? I mean, Christ -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Something! You're the sheriff for God's sake!

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: (as peacemaker; overlapping) Edward --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You're supposed to protect us -- !

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: (to Edward; overlapping) Hey! HEY!! This ain't helping, Eddie. We're all in the same boat here. Edward simmers down. Feels no real rancor toward David. Just can't handle the situation.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Anybody heard what it is yet? What they spilled? Nobody has.  41.

dialogues.speaker: TOWN PLANNER
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, they’re keeping us here till it’s cleaned up. Whole town’s sealed off. Roadblocks, everything. Tim Mitchell tried to run one of ‘em, they shot him dead. It’s the guy who gave David the pipeline schematic, here his ten-year-old son. Other children are in tears. Some o the parents as well. A DISTRAUGHT MOM breaks down at the sight of David.

dialogues.speaker: DISTRAUGHT MOM
dialogues.text: Amy’s out there... my Amy... He embraces her, not knowing what to say. A tall open-fac guy named SHELDON steps forward, local choir director clinging to his faith.

dialogues.speaker: SHELDON
dialogues.text: I know things look bad right now, I know they do, but like they say in every tragedy there's a blessing --

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE TEACHER
dialogues.text: (angry) What's our blessing, Sheldon? I'm dying to hear this one.

dialogues.speaker: SHELDON
dialogues.text: We're not sick yet. Which means we still got a chance. A blessing indeed. Suddenly, the SQUEAL OF BRAKES. The truck slowing. Lots of NOISE outside. A look of panic sweeps the group. David rips a metal brace from the wall. weapon. The truck STOPS. Parents shield their kids as the door is unlocked. It swings open. SHADOWY FIGURES rush through. David comes at them, ready to attack when he sees they ar RESCUE WORKERS (in less severe biosuits, faces visible) offering bottles of spring water and Powerbars.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE WORKER
dialogues.text: Quickly, people. We're getting you out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and the others step warily from the truck, take in their surroundings. A TRUCKSTOP being used as an operatio staging area. Military trucks refueling.  42. Transport helicopters coming and going from the adjoining field. Supplies and troops being shuttled to and fro. In the fenced-in parking lot where the livestock truck is few HUNDRED SURVIVORS await evacuation, getting treatment first aid tents. A SITE COORDINATOR stands on a military flatbed megaphoning instructions to a LINE OF SURVIVORS b processed for transport:

dialogues.speaker: SITE COORDINATOR
dialogues.text: As you board the buses you will each be given a dispensation card, it looks like this, do not lose it, you will not be allowed into the safe zone without your dispensation card... GREEN PLASTIC BARCODED BRACELETS being snapped on wrists hurriedly scanned into handheld computers. Temperatures taken one last time. Visible relief on people's faces as they look toward the EVACUATION BUSES idling nearby. As David and the others take their place in line, a small miracle. The distraught mom spots her little girl. Bursts into tears -

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hugs her, frantically relieved. The reunion only heighten David's loss. As he surveys the truckstop, plotting his escape:

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: Whatever you're thinking. There's one way out of here and it's on those buses. You got a seat on one. A seat a lot of people wish they had.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let ‘em have it.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: David. This might your last chance. Don’t lose it running off on some fool's errand.  43.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Judy's a fool's errand?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN MILLER
dialogues.text: You know what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tell you what, Kev. You don't ask me why I can't leave without my wife and I won't ask you why you can. A bit harsh but right on the money. Kevin Miller is left nurse his guilty conscience as David takes off. We run with him down the narrow passage between two big r Quick stop. TWO ARMED GUARDS on patrol. David ducks under the trailers, hiding until they’re gone. Moves on. Squeezing through some temporary fencing, he jumps in the back of a SUPPLY TRUCK headed back into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEDATED TOWNSPEOPLE strapped to gurneys in a social studi classroom. Among them we find JUDY, semi-conscious, shove in here amid the overturned desks. An EXAMINER works from field kit, not providing medical care, taking tissue and blood samples. GUNFIRE erupts outside. The examiner stops his work and stares out the window. He doesn’t move. Something terribl is happening out there. Craning her neck, Judy can see

dialogues.speaker: THE BALLFIELD DOWN THE HILL
dialogues.text: where PANDEMONIUM has broken out. CRAZED TOWNSPEOPLE attacking examiners, murdering medtechs. They overwhelm t guards, shoot them with their own weapons, pull down the fence at center field, causing a stampede.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE PRISONERS RUN INTO THE WOODS LIKE LUNATICS FLEEIN
dialogues.text: ASYLUM. The perimeter soldiers converge and open fire, bu they can’t stop the escape. Seen through the haze of sedation, the horror is dreamlik Judy's eyes flutter closed. Helpless on her gurney. Yesterday’s homework assignment chalked on the blackboard above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting among stacks of BOXES, David watches the moonlit prairie go by. Like a practical joke, an old ROAD SIGN go past: "Welcome to Marsh County. Friendliest Place on Earth." David looks at the boxes, curious what’s inside. He opens one. Wishes he hadn't. BODY BAGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TICKING clock. Pot of coffee on the coffeemaker. The door CREAKS open. David, crouched like a thief, hurries to his desk, grabs his spare revolver, some bullets. A shotgun f the gun rack. Shells. Loading up, he catches sight of something horrific. Drops box of shells. On the floor of the holding cell - BILL FARNUM HIDEOUSLY CONTORTED IN DEATH. His back arched high off the floor. Neck tendons, obscenely tight, practically tearing the jaw from his face. David steps back, right onto the BARREL OF A SHOTGUN aime his head.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Easy. David raises his arms, turns.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Chief?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stop surprising me like that. Manly embrace. David goes to look at Farnum again. Russel obstructs.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Don’t look at that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They let you guys out?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Let us? People went nuts. Tore the place apart. It was like a human slaughterhouse. I just ran.  45. Sound of a SPEEDING CAR interrupts them. They duck the FL of its headlights. It’s that same BLACK SUBURBAN TEARING PAST THE POLICE STATION at ninety miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Judy, man, I tried to stop ‘em. David nods, gathering shells from the floor. Stands, man a mission.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m going to get her. Russell doublepumps the shotgun, the stress of the situat bringing out his redneck roots.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hoo-fuckin'-yah, chief, let's go to the high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HYSTERICAL SHRIEKS and SCREAMS fill the school. Violent chaos spilling from the classrooms. An EXAMINER runs down second-floor corridor past a half-dressed LUNATIC roaming halls in a head bandage.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINER
dialogues.text: (to staff) Let’s go! Forget it, we're leaving! We are leaving! EXAMINERS scramble for the exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EXAMINER drawing blood samples hears the evacuation order. Grabs his things and runs out, accidentally leavin needle embedded in the last victim’s arm. Blood drips ont the floor. PLIP. PLIP. PLIP. We move up the arm to the face... It’s JUDY. She stares at the dripping blood. Hands strapped, she can do anything to stop it.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXAMINERS and MEDTECHS jump in helicopters. SOLDIERS into trucks. It’s obvious what’s happening. The military is pulling out, conceding town center to the lunatics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Russell, avoiding the main streets, cut through series of backyards in a dark residential neighborhood. T night reverberates with DISTANT POPS of gunfire. They hop fence and David grabs Russell, pulls him sharply back.

dialogues.speaker: A PSYCHOTIC HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: sits at a picnic table in a bathrobe gutting a turkey. Creepy uncomprehending stare. Her HUSBAND noosed from a t behind her.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOTIC HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Did Peter call? Madness. They move on, hop the other fence. The housewife screaming in the b.g. -

dialogues.speaker: DID PETER CALL
dialogues.text: As they distance themselves, a look of dread comes to Russell’s face.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: That's gonna be me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Right out of my goddamn tree like my Uncle Willard who swears on the Bible he ate a tadpole and shat out a bullfrog, and that’s without the screwy water so --

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russ, we got enough problems without you inventing ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say, you’re at the end of the pipeline. I’m half a mile from the Farnums.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who's the sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who's the sheriff of Marsh County?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am. Who's the deputy?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You are. Deputy does what the sheriff tells him, that's the balance of power. Now I'm telling you you're not getting sick, understand? Russell nods, appreciating the sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hope you're right, chief. I'm no world beater but I had plans. Crossing a street, they see MILITARY HELICOPTERS, perhaps mile away, lifting off into the night sky. David, alarmed quickens his stride.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s the school! They’re bailing! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLIP. PLIP. PLIP. Judy watching herself bleed. She could die like this. One drip at a time. Gritting her teeth, pronating her forearm, she manages to painfully scrape th needle from her arm on the side of the gurney. In the aftermath of the military exodus there is an eerie calm filled with SHRIEKS and GROANS, the INSANE RANTINGS the abandoned inmates. With those horrible sounds in her ears Judy scans the classroom. Her fellow townspeople. Varying degrees of madness on display: A middle-aged WOMAN SNICKERING to herself. A teenage BOY BABBLING incoherently.  48. A CATATONIC MAN with the same half dead, half twitching f Bill Farnum had. Others are unconscious, comatose, drooli Judy locks eyes, unexpectedly, with a high school girl strapped down on the other side of the room. Terrified, trembling, but otherwise asymptomatic. BECCA DARLING. Her office helper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Becca?! Becca, honey, are you hurt...?! Becca, deep in shock, trembling in terror:

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Is this... really happening...? Judy puts on a brave face, doctorly instincts taking over

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, it’ll be okay. All right?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: You don’t really believe that, do you? Becca calls her bluff and suddenly it’s Judy battling emotions. Near tears, she shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where’s your mom and dad?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: We were hiding... we tried to get away... The sentence ends in SOBS. Her parents are dead. Judy tug at her restraints, wants to get over there to help but ca And now they have bigger problems. A terrible sound draws their gazes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY.
dialogues.text: Somebody's coming. You can hear their SHUFFLING STEPS. Ju shoots Becca a look. Be very quiet. Becca stifles her sob as the creepy scraping noise comes CLOSER, CLOSER... And now it stops. The classroom door swings open with a CREAK. A figure silhouetted in the doorway. Image from a nightmare:  49. A pot-bellied LUNATIC drenched in blood. BRUCE WEBBER. Th A & P Manager. He is dragging a PITCHFORK. Judy and Becca watch in mute terror, praying he’1ll leave Instead he enters. Drags the pitchfork to the nearest gur and looks down at the insane snickering woman. He mumbles something nonsensical then raises the pitchfor and SPEARS HER in the chest. Becca SCREAMS. Bruce extract the pitchfork from his first victim and shuffles to his second. The babbling boy. SPEARS HIM and continues his murderous ritual, heading straight for Becca who is thrashing wildly but will never escape. Judy fights to free her hands, to save Becca. She can’t. Stabbing everyone in his path, Bruce arrives at Becca who closes her eyes as the lunatic raises his pitchfork. Just then, Judy from the other side of the room:

dialogues.speaker: NOOOO
dialogues.text: The kind of scream even a lunatic can’t ignore. Bruce sto turns. Sees Judy over there, strapped down by the blackboard, helpless. Nudging desks aside, he comes for h instead. Hands pinned at her side, Judy stretches her fingertips j far enough to reach the blackboard chalk tray and, using as a rail, gets the gurney rolling. Rolls herself right o the classroom door, gripping whatever’s within reach. Bruce follows her out, dragging the pitchfork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy rolls down the row of lockers, grabbing the PADLOCKS with that strapped hand, pulling herself along. The SOUND THE PITCHFORK right behind her. Blind panic setting in. H diversion play quickly shaping up as suicide. Craning her neck she can see Bruce coming. Quickens her pace, fingers grabbing frantically at the padlocks. And t tragedy strikes.

dialogues.speaker: HER HAND
dialogues.text: misses the next lock, the last one in this row, and as a result she misses the turn. And drifts helplessly into th center of the corridor...  50. The wheels of her gurney CREAK to a stop. Her EYES wide w terror. Her FINGERS still clutching at the air. STRANDED a trophy case of old basketballs. The STEEL PRONGS OF THE PITCHFORK dragging closer. And no

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: shuffles into view. Stands above her, leering. The ROW OF PADLOCKS swinging behind him like a hundred little pendul As he raises the pitchfork -

dialogues.speaker: A SHOTGUN BLAST
dialogues.text: Catches him in the arm, spinning him fully around as a SE BLAST RIPS A SIX-INCH HOLE IN HIS CHEST. Bruce Webber fal in a heap, never comprehending his death. David and Russe run to Judy, Russell standing guard as David unstraps her

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Not really. Unstrapped, she takes off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy unstraps Becca. Becca cries in her arms. Judy holds her as she might her own child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREDATORY LUNATICS wander the streets, maimed, bleeding, faces half dead. They attack each other at random, some unleashing the same murderous fury on inanimate objects. predatory types stagger through the night babbling. CRAZE CHILDREN running around like orphans of the apocalypse. David, Judy, Russell and Becca jog along Main Street, pas shattered shopfronts and parked cars that have been BOOTE prevent driving.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Nobody's driving outta here. An APACHE GUNSHIP flies by overhead. Shockingly fast. Shockingly loud. David and the others duck around the cor by the bank. Looks of terror on their faces, knowing they the targets.  51. They run on. Up ahead, a YOUNG MOTHER sits breast-feeding her baby on the curb. She’s sobbing, rocking on her heels Judy slows. David keeps her moving.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s Molly Hutchins.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can’t help her. And we see the baby in the young mother’s arms is not a b A PLASTIC DOLL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross a wide field PULSING with cicadas. A mile from town center it’s almost peaceful. The occasional burst of gunfire in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That truckstop where fifty hits the county line, they're taking people out of there, putting them on buses.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wichita maybe, wherever, some safe zone.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hell of a walk, county line.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My cruiser's back at the house.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: We'll be sitting ducks on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm thinking the power line road. It's crap, but we can drive it.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Leaves us about a mile on foot.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Exactly.  52. Judy falls behind, stops in the middle of the field. The others look back at her, then to David - what’s going on? walks back to her. She stands, arms folded, trying to hid her fear.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What if they’re right? What if I’m sick? (includes Becca) What if we both are?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’re not sick.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Saying it doesn’t make it true.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
