dialogues.text: If you're sick, I’m sick -- we drank from the same tap -- and I’m not sick. Not yet anyway. So let's keep walking. They head back to the others, Judy with lingering relucta the issue not entirely settled in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide, flat, glimmering with the same toxic sheen as the b David and the others step carefully from stone to stone.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (to David) See those folks in town? Man oh man, makes you wonder, don’t it? ‘Bout human nature?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s not human nature’s doing this, it’s a chemical.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Actin’ on an instinct that’s already there or they’d be group- huggin’ instead of tearing each other apart. Becca slips on a mossy rock and PLUNGES INTO THE STREAM.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shit! Get her out of there!  53. They pull her out and tend to her on the opposite bank. Becca sits sobbing in the aftermath, scared to death, soa from head to toe.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, we’ll get you some dry clothes at the house. Judy shares a private look of concern with David, both noticing the creek’s toxic sheen. Becca sees it, too, and draws her own conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: (shuddering sobs) I’m... gonna... die... Russell takes off his deputy coat and puts it over Becca warmth. Squats in front of her, sheriff-in-the-making.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You're getting out of here. I just made that my duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome moves in wary tandem, skirting the perimeter an old farm. A barn. Three silos. Judy walks beside Becca who is cold, shivering, and generally miserable, but mana to strike a lighter note:

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Guess this means no prom, huh? Judy half smiles, nods yeah. David's hand flies up, halti the group. He gestures 'stay' then walks on alone a bit farther. Listens. Comes rushing back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Down down down! They all hit the ground. Hearts pounding. Listening. Davi and Russell draw their guns. David indicates the hillcres And now the enemy comes into view, moonshadowed and letha A PLATOON OF BIOSUITED SOLDIERS wading through the tall g in infrared goggles. One of them is carrying a FLAMETHROW

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Oh man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In there. THREE SILOS behind them. They crawl through the grass.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the hatch and watch through RUST HOLES as the soldi storm the farmhouse. We hear a SHRIEK inside the house and moments later the soldiers emerge, dragging a CRYING WOMAN off the porch in the front yard. They stand her up. Somebody jams a digita thermometer in her ear. BEEP-BEEP-BEEP. BANG! They shoot her. Point blank. A battlefield execution. The guy with the FLAMETHROWER steps up and torches the body. David's anger overwhelms his judgement. He reaches for th hatch. Russell grabs his arm - no, chief. Flushed with rage, David tries to pull away, but Russell holds strong. And David's good senses returns. He backs down. But they’ doomed anyway. A SOLDIER IS HEADED OVER TO CHECK THE SILOS. He checks the first then the second, working his way towa the last one, the one they're hiding in. Panic sweeps the group. David searches for some miracle escape. Up. Down. Left. Right. There is nothing. The only exit is

dialogues.speaker: THAT HATCH
dialogues.text: Through the rust holes we see the SOLDIER creeping toward with his assault rifle. Russell readying his weapons. Dav his. Judy in disbelief. Becca whimpering with fright.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (softly) Shut her up! Judy clamps her hand over Becca’s mouth as THE HATCH DOOR CREAKS OPEN. The MUZZLE OF AN M-16 enters first. Then the soldier’s GASMASKED FACE. To the right he sees nothing, to the left RUSSELL who smacks him in the head with his rifle butt, knocking him down. David and Russell drag the semi-consci soldier into the silo and close the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pray they don't do a headcount.  55. They wait on pins and needles to see if the missing soldi will be noticed. The platoon regroups in front of the hou and MOVES ON WITHOUT HIM. Gasps of relief. Judy uncovers Becca’s mouth. Becca doubl over crying. Russell yanks off the soldier's helmet, read to crush his skull with the rifle butt. But the face behi the mask is not the face of an enemy... AN EIGHTEEN-YEAR-OLD BOY. Scared as hell. Far from home.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Aw Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: The young private sits against the silo wall, welt on his forehead where Russell smacked him. Blue-collar kid froma blue-collar state. Well-mannered. West Virginia drawl. PVT. BILLY BABCOCK. He's scared. They are the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Billy Babcock... David gestures to the yard outside, to the execution they just witnessed -- a silent seething ‘why’?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Orders, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: From who?!

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Whoever gives ‘em, I dunno. (then) Are y'all gonna shoot me? Judy answers for David and Russell.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Then can you have him stop pointin' that thing?  56. Russell's shotgun aimed at his head. David gives Russell look and Russell lowers it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Billy, I want you to tell me what exactly the fuck is going on down here.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: I dunno. All's they said was there'd been some accident. My whole unit got flown in. We didn't even know what state we was in till we saw the license plates.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: There wasn’t anything on the news? Before you left?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: No, ma’am. From what I hear they're doing one of them media blackouts. David and Judy exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Am I gonna die breathing without my mask?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Is that what they said?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: They just said keep it on. Troubled pause. Judy tosses him his gasmask. He straps it on over his face, breathes and talks through it the rest the scene.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nobody's said anything about what it was they spilled?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: No, sir, but -- I’m probably not supposed to talk about this, but my sergeant, he saw this computer program they ran over at central, some kinda 'casualty projection' I think he called it, you know, to see how things were gonna turn out down here.  Gulp. 57.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Nobody lived past the third day.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Nobody?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Crazies killed most of ‘em, sickness got the rest. Today’s the second day, I’d get out of here tonight if I was you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How? The truckstop?

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Dunno, sir. Perimeter's pretty hardcore. Even for healthies, they're giving ‘em one warning shot then it's a kill order. (then) Look, um, I know I don’t deserve no favors from you people, but if you let me go I swear to God I won’t come back, they can courtmartial me, I don’t care, I didn’t sign up to shoot unarmed civilians. I’11l just leave. Okay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testing the waters, he starts to stand up. Russell levels his gun. David nods

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Cool it, Russ.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: He'll give away our location.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're not staying here. ‘go ahead' to the boy. He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Reckon you're keeping that, huh?  58. His M-16 and AMMO CLIPS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're gonna hold onto those, Billy. Billy nods okay. Steps to the hatch. Pauses there.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Sorry 'bout your folks's town. Then exits, running off into the night, opposite directio his platoon. David grabs the M-16 and ammo clips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they come out the hatch:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Why aren't they telling anybody what’s going on down here? David pauses, Russell’s question hanging.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (indicates) That’s why. THE BURNING CORPSE. They just stare, the firelight playin across their haunted faces.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let’s get to the house. They set off and we see the farmhouse from a distance. Al on the prairie. A plume of smoke rising up ghostly pale i the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come up through the back acres. David with the M-16 his shoulder. Judy offering a grave assessment.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This wasn’t a chemical spill. (off their looks) They're burning the bodies. It must be bacteriological, viral. Something that spreads by human contact. Or the air.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: The air? -- it was in the water.  59. Judy gives a grim nod.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It was. It must have more than one mode of transmission. Or mutated or something, who knows.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (to Judy) How come I’m not crazy yet?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I told you why.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (to Judy) Besides the fact that your husband officially forbade it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Expose a group of people to something, there’s always a handful who aren’t affected. I don’t know, Russell, maybe you’re naturally immune.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Nah, I’m not that lucky. They walk on. Judy’s face darkens as THEIR HOUSE comes in view at the top of the field. Curtains sway in shattered windows. The cruiser, gutted by fire, smolders in the driveway. Caught up in her emotions, she dashes toward th house with David, Russell and Becca playing catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Judy, wait!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ALTERNATE POV (STATIC) - Through a lace-curtained upstair window, we see them run across the field to the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy runs in the front door and slows, shocked - THE HOUSE IS DESTROYED. Holes smashed through the walls. Sofas and chairs slashed open. The upright piano decimate David enters and surveys the destruction with Judy as Rus checks the other rooms to make sure there's nobody here.  60. Judy turns and walks out, past Becca who has stopped at t front door out of simple respect. David lingers a moment then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy at the clothesline taking down the laundry. David wa over.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (no reply) Stop. He catches her hands. Judy breaks down, dropping clothes. David holds her beside the fluttering white sheets.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (re: house) None of this matters. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (crying) I don't care about the house... it's everything. Everybody. Everybody we know... I don't see how we recover from this... I don't see how this town ever comes back... Neither does David. He holds her close.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ALTERNATE POV - Through a downstairs window, we see David Judy outside by the clothesline. LOW RASPY BREATHS. Someone, inside the house, is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy walks away from the house to clear her head. Becca following, hoping to console. David comes up the steps pa Russell who sits at the top, wiping sweat from his brow w a handkerchief. Russell nods at the smoldering cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Sheriff-mobile's seen better days.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (nods ) We'll have to take our chances on the highway. Power lines will take too long.  61. Tosses Russell the M-16.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stay with them, I'll be right back. Russell nods and goes off across the lawn to catch the gi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overturned appliances. Food spilled on the floor. David grabs some BOTTLED WATER and tosses it in a dufflebag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bowling motion he slides the dufflebag the length the hall to the front door as he heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cresting the stairs, David comes down the hall to the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops in the doorway, shocked. It’s a bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: A BLOOD-SOAKED SHEET
dialogues.text: covers two corpses on the bed. Who's under there? David steps closer, draws back the sheet -

dialogues.speaker: TWO SLAUGHTERED PIGS
dialogues.text: Their severed heads on the pillows suggest a husband and wife. David places his hand on a carcass, checking for warmth. His face darkens. Fresh kills. He tenses at a sudden scary thought.

dialogues.speaker: IS THERE SOMEONE UNDER THE BED
dialogues.text: He backs slowly away, angling his gaze underneath. BARE FLOOR. A moment of relief and then with renewed dread he slowly turns to face the doorway, realizing the killers are more likely behind him, hiding in the house, perhaps somewhere down this dark upstairs hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David steps into the hall. Tense breath and then he start down it. Very slowly. Trying not to make a sound. Sensitive to the slightest CREAKS of the floorboards.  62. Halfway to the stairs he STOPS ABRUPTLY, thinking he hear something. Listens. Nothing. The house is eerily still. Silent except for the curtains billowing in the broken windows. He continues on. Heel to toe. Heart pounding. Each closed door a potential hiding place. Ten feet in front of him o the left, that door looks particularly suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: open a crack. David’s eyes are riveted to it as he approaches, convinced it will fly open any second. But th attack comes from an open door to his right, from the hal painted nursery. As he passes - A GARBAGE BAG IS YANKED OVER HIS HEAD and he is hit - WHA flat across the chest with a pipe. The blow sends him flying backwards. Bag on his head, Dav is kicked in the gut and dragged into the master bedroom his feet, the plastic sucking back into his mouth as he g for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is thrown across the room into the bureau. CRASH! EXT. DOWN THE ROAD —- CONTINUOUS Judy, walking away, looks back at the house. The windblow grass drowning out b.g. noises.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? Becca shakes her head. Russell too. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staggering to his feet, David claws at the plastic bag covering his face, ripping it away to finally see his attackers.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE AND CURT HAMILL
dialogues.text: Faces half paralyzed, half in spasm, wrenched into hideou lopsided sneers. Jake grabs the knife he used to slaughter the pigs and ma a lunging stab. David's hand flies up in a reflexive bloc  63. THE KNIFE POINT COMES OUT THE BACK OF DAVID’S HAND! In and out, a flash of steel. David recoils clutching his hand, blood pouring down. Curt swings a pipe at his head. Barely misses. David stumbles backwards onto the bed, sandwiched between the slaughtered pigs. Jake jumps astride him, drives the knife two-handed at David's chest. David catches him by the wrists, sends him tumbling off the side of the bed, and rolls off the other side as Curt brings the pipe down like a sledgehammer at face. The pipe hits the pillow instead. FEATHERS EXPLODE EVERYWHERE. David climbs to his feet, fumbling for something to fight with. Grabs the phone book. A poor choice. The Hamill boy back him into the corner. Feathers swirling. Curt unleash another swing of the pipe. WHAM! David partly blocks it with the Yellow Pages, but the for sends him flying backwards out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH! - David flies through and tumbles off the porch ro onto the lawn below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, Becca and Russell whip around.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They run for the house, but they're too far away to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David tries to crawl away, but there's no escape. The Ham boys emerge from the house, closing in for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, Judy and Becca running as fast as they can.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They can't reach him before the Hamill boys do. Knowing this, Russell drops to one knee with his revolver and fir TWO QUICK SHOTS from the neighbor's yard - POP! POP!  64. Dead-centers a round in each of the Hamill boys' chests. slows them but doesn’t stop them completely. Instantly up and running again, Russell puts another two rounds in eac brother on the move - POP-POP! POP-POP! - dropping them i their tracks five feet from David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy runs to David's side, near hysterics. Badly shaken himself, he puts his arm around her. Blood courses down h cheek from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: David oh my God let me see! LET ME

dialogues.speaker: SEE
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand. Blood pooling in the upturned palm

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, David... She flips it over, sees the exit wound.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: ...it went through?! He nods yeah, rattled to the core. Becca runs to the clothesline, grabs a T-shirt. Tears off a strip. Ties the first loop around David wrist as a tourniquet and wraps t rest around his palm as a bandage.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Too tight? David shakes his head, it’s fine. Quick thinking by Becca Judy clasps her hand - thanks. This whole time Russell stands over the dead brothers in the b.g. Staring down at them. And then things get WEIRD: He reloads and puts three more bullets in the head of eac brother, slowly, deliberately, savoring each shot. With dawning horror David and Judy watch as he reloads a secon time and continues - BANG! BANG! BANG! BANG! Judy can't watch anymore.

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: Russell fires one last RESOUNDING SHOT and then, after a pause, walks over and pulls David to his feet, the loyal deputy again.  65.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (seeing David's injury) Still with us?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. How ‘bout you? Russell catches David’s look and his meaning. Casts a gla at the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Just making sure. David nods okay. Judy and Becca staring in silence at the two bullet-riddled teenagers on the front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: House in the b.g., the group heads down the road. David a Judy share a private word about Russell who walks just ah the M-16 on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He’s infected.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You saw what he did.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He saved my life, that’s what I saw. End of discussion. David lengthens his stride to catch up with Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrow-straight to its vanishing point. David, Judy, Becca and Russell come into view. It’s hot and getting hotter. One of those midsummer days where you feel the heat by 10 David stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Goddammit. He turns and looks back the way they came, cursing under breath.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I left the water at the house.  66.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: How far to the truckstop?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fifteen miles.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What do we do? Russell grins at the HOT SUN.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: We fry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through SHIMMERING HEAT WAVES we see the highway. The foursome in the distance like a mirage. Then in CLOSEUP. Damp shirts. Faces beaded with sweat. Russell takes off his shirt and walks on bare chested. Strong. Sinewy. Humming some 70’s rock song to himself. David watches him, trying to gauge his sanity. Deflects Judy's look of concern with:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’d worry about her. Indicates Becca, who has fallen behind. Judy goes back, checks on her.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: I feel sick.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What kind of sick?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Dizzy. Judy takes Becca by the elbow, helping her along. Just th A GUNSHOT splits the silence. David spins, where did that come from? And before the group can orient themselves - ANOTHER GUNSHOT, closer than the first. They dive in the ditch as -

dialogues.speaker: A PICKUP TRUCK
dialogues.text: comes four-wheeling across the field.  67.

dialogues.speaker: THREE REDNECK PSYCHOS
dialogues.text: in blood-soaked hunter vests howling out the windows, fir rifles. Tied down across the hood is the body of

dialogues.speaker: PVT. BILLY BABCOCK
dialogues.text: Naked. Gutted like a deer. David and the others stare numbly at this latest horror. The pickup tearing through old barbed wire fence as it races off across the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More walking. More sweat. Judy, helping Becca as before, spots a BINGO HALL set back from the highway on a dirt ro An old COUPE DE VILLE parked in the lot.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: David. He nods, already spotted it. Russell doesn’t seem to real they've stopped and continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey Russ. Russell doesn’t hear him, keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russell! Russell never turns, never slows. David watches, worried.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where he’s going?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (has no idea) Let’s get the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white peaked-roof bingo hall sits alone on the prairie a church without a steeple. David, Judy and Becca cross t parking lot. A haunting VOICE echoes inside the building, stops them dead in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy trade looks. He cocks his handgun and they continue toward the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a carpeted lobby. Framed pictures of happy winners on the wall. And here, a WATER FOUNTAIN. Becca, thirst-crazed, goes straight for it. Steps on the pedal. HISSES and SPUTTERS. No water.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Can't drink it anyway. Becca releases the pedal. And now that haunting voice com over the PA system:

dialogues.speaker: I-21...
dialogues.text: They all look to the set of double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors seen from the other side as they open. David, J and Becca stepping through, warily, to scan the dark hall MAN'S VOICE ON P.A. G-47... Standing in the shadows at the far end, under the big illuminated Bingo flashboard, an OLD MAN IN A SHRINER’S H is reading the numbers off ping pong balls as they fly up chute into his hand from an electric blower-tumbler.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (calls to him) That your car out front? No reply, no acknowledgement whatsoever from the old shri He reads another ball.

dialogues.speaker: OLD BINGO SHRINER
dialogues.text: (over PA system) N-32... They walk up the aisle toward him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey, is that your car out there?

dialogues.speaker: OLD BINGO SHRINER
dialogues.text: (over PA system) 0-67...  69.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Can we borrow the keys? They stop ten feet away. The old shriner holds out his ha palm downturned, as if to offer David something. A beat t - FSSHHTUNK - a ping pong ball flies up into it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD BINGO SHRINER
dialogues.text: (over PA system) I-29... Judy spots someone in the shadows. There, sitting among t empty tables on the other side of the room - A MORBIDLY

dialogues.speaker: OBESE MAN IN SUSPENDERS LEANED INTENTLY OVER HIS BINGO CA
dialogues.text: She walks over to him, David and Becca close behind.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, is that your -- She recoils in horror. The fat man is two days dead. Thro slit. Jaw gaping at his blood-caked Bingo card. They all stand there for a moment processing the image. A five-hundred pound corpse with a Bingo card. Rolls of decomposing fat overhanging the chair he’s sitting in. Ow of the Coupe De Ville? Judy steps closer. Holding her breath at the stench, reminding herself she’s doctor, she slips her hand into the dead man’s shirt pock Empty. Right pant pocket. Empty. Left side. Empty. She can’t reach the back ones. He’s sitting on them.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Help me lift him. Startled looks of ‘who us?’ from David and Becca. A look reply from Judy, ‘yes, you two’. They come over and take hold.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: On three. One... Two... Three! As they wrestle with the man’s decomposing bulk, the dead weight shifts unexpectedly, slipping -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shit, get back! The massive corpse goes CRASHING to the floor, the BELLY SPLITTING OPEN on one side unleashing a torrent of blood innards and liquefied fat. Judy stands in that mess, repulsed. Holds up her hand.  70. CAR KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit to find RUSSELL sitting on the bumper of the Co De Ville. Pissed off, pouring sweat, M-16 across his lap.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Guys trying to ditch me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russ, I called to ya, you kept walking. We were gonna pick you up down the road. Russell says nothing, dubious. David puts the keys in the ignition. Says a little prayer and gives it a try. The engine turns over twice and STARTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty highway. The Coupe De Ville comes into view at a cautious thirty miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David drives, scanning the horizon for danger. Judy doing the same from the passenger seat. Russell sits bare-chest in the back seat with Becca. Whispers to her, paranoid:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: He called to me back there?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: Twice.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Loud enough to hear? Becca nods yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Then why didn’t I hear him? Judy shushes everybody.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Listen! They all go silent. And now we hear it, the sound of an oncoming

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit. They’re sitting ducks out here. David punches th gas, spins the tires - SCREEEECH!! A burst of acceleratio followed by a sudden stop as he pulls the car off the roa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - into the wash bay of an automated car wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David kills the engine, everybody pitching their ears to fast-approaching ROAR overheard -— VROOOM! - the Apache comes screaming down the highway. Follows the road to its vanishing point. Gone. But the threat remains.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We can’t stay on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (forced patience) What would you recommend, dear?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You said something about the powerline road.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're five miles the other way now. Becca, in the back, looks out the window and GASPS. A HIDEOUS HALF-DEAD FACE watching them from the car wash lo

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: There’s somebody in there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: (pointing) I saw someone. They all stare at the lobby. There’s nobody there.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Let's go. David reaches for the ignition, but before his hand gets there -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tracks engage the front tires, yanking the car forwar into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Holy fuck!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: What’s happening?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Somebody turned it on! An overhead spray nozzle sprays its residual water and th SPUTTERING DRY, pukes PINK LIQUID SOAP all over the windshield, blinding them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, GET US OUT OF HERE
dialogues.text: He starts the engine, punches the gas, but the tires, cov in pink slime, JUST SPIN in the tracks. They’1l have to r it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: A HIDEOUS TWITCHING FACE
dialogues.text: Judy catches a glimpse of it through the swirling machine

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Over there!! David and Russell spin to look, but their view is obstruc as -

dialogues.speaker: BIG SPINNING BRUSHES
dialogues.text: swing into frame, whipping at the windows and body panels flinging the pink soap off in gooey tendrils. And now Bec sees out the back -

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SINISTER FACE
dialogues.text: She loses it. David whips his head around to see, but the brush comes spinning down off the roof and across the bac window, blinding him. Heightened terror. All the windows covered in soap. The DEAFENING HUM of the MACHINERY. Becca, hysterical, crouch on the floor -

dialogues.speaker: BECCA DARLING
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna die like this!  73. A DARK SHAPE zips past Russell’s window. He freaks. Rolls it down and GOES FULLY AUTOMATIC WITH THE M-16, spraying bullets everywhere. David and the others cover their ears the DEAFENING GUNFIRE only adding to the terror.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Crazed, Russell keeps firing, empties the clip. Tosses th spent weapon out the window. Rolls it up again. Turning t tell David:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I saw movement!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: EVERYTHING’S FUCKING MOVING!! A momentary calm as the BRUSHES RETRACT. And then - WHAM! - The SWAYING CHAMOIS DRYERS hit the windshield, ma everybody jump. David fires a reflexive shot through the windshield, then steadies himself. The LONG TENTACLES OF FABRIC engulf the car, shimmying ac the windows like living creatures. It’s creepy. God knows what they conceal. David tries the gas again - WHIRRRRRRRR. We hear the tires spinning. David keeps them going, inching the car forward by that small coefficient friction.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, come on... Suddenly, as they clear the tentacles -

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: The driver’s side window EXPLODES behind David’s head, spraying the interior with glass fragments. Almost simultaneously the rear window EXPLODES, a cinder block landing in the back seat. A LUNATIC FACE flies in at David through his shattered window, teeth bared like a rabid dog. David deflects the bite to the steering wheel where it takes a chunk out of rubber, exposing the steel below. David counters with a vicious elbow that crushes the lunatic’s nose and sends him reeling backwards against th wall. Another LUNATIC walks up onto the hood of the car, holding a cinder block above his head that is destined fo the windshield. Judy screams, shielding her face.  74.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: CRASH! The windshield shatters. The car roof caves in as THIRD LUNATIC jumps on top and trampolines. And now the first lunatic is back at the window, a human pit bull, Da barely holding him off by the throat as he starts the eng with his other hand. The first lunatic lashes out, loops a RINSE HOSE around David's neck. A noose. The lunatic on the roof yanks it taut using the overhead swing arm as a winch to pry David of the car. Choking, head jammed against the ceiling, David throws th car into the reverse, creating slack in the hose. Judy frantically unwinds it from his neck. Freed, David goes f throttle. The WHIRRRRRRR of the spinning tires becomes a piercing SCREEEEEEECH as they catch the asphalt at the en the tracks. But at the last second, one of the lunatics loops the hos around BECCA’S NECK As the car peels out, the hose snaps taut and YANKS HER

dialogues.speaker: BACKWARDS OUT THE REAR WINDOW
dialogues.text: Judy whips around SCREAMING, jams her foot on the brake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumps out and runs to Becca who is dangling from the swin arm. David and Russell jump out right behind her, droppin the attackers at close range. BANG! BANG! BANG! BANG!

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: Judy grabs Becca around the torso, supporting her weight she tries to get the hose from around her neck. A despera effort and a futile one. The hose is too tight and BECCA IS DEAD. Neck snapped. Noosed by the high-pressure hose. David comes over, turns Judy away. She fights it and then reality hits. She hammers her fists on his chest in anger and then collapses against him in grief, sobbing. Meanwhile, in the b.g., the Coupe De Ville, left idling i neutral, rolls across the lot and comes to a stop in the road. It sits there idling as Judy returns to Becca now, needing to get her down.  75.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Help me! David pulls his knife and cuts the hose. Becca slumps int Judy's arms. Judy cradles her down into a seated position weeping over the girl’s body. The scene would end on that image, but it’s here that the APACHE revisits them. SCREAMING across the prairie to ope fire on the exposed Coupe De Ville. Bullets strafe the ca lengthwise. It catches fire and burns. They watch in silence. Russell nodding to himself like a reveling in God’s authority. David and Judy's expressions edging toward doom. The smoke, blowing across their faces paints Judy’s tears black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on. Judy looks ready to give up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: They’1l never let us in without testing us. I already failed that test once.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And you know why.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, David. Even if you're right, how are we gonna prove it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm feeling persuasive. Up ahead is a FAMILY STATION WAGON stopped by a spike str David checks the ignition as they walk up. KEYS. He reaches in, tries to start the engine.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: The tires are flat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It'll drive on the rims. The engine turns over, won't start. He pops the hood. All the SPARK PLUG CABLES HAVE BEEN CUT.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bastards.  76. Slams the hood down. Moment of despair. David looks weari down the highway. Hears something behind them. A CAR APPROACHING. There in the distance, coming fast.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Move! They all take cover behind the station wagon. Here it com racing down the highway...

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll help.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you just block out the last seventy-two hours of your life? They're not even gonna stop.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Sure, they are. With a deranged smile Russell kicks the SPIKE STRIP - bur in the dirt behind the stopped wagon - across the road.

dialogues.speaker: SIDEWAYS AND GOES INTO A BARREL ROLL.
dialogues.text: Pieces fly off as it tumbles. A bumper. A door. It comes to rest on its side in the cornfield. Russell goes joggin off toward it, rifle in hand. David and Judy in utter sho

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: If they’re alive he’ll kill ‘em. David takes off after Russell, hollering his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nondescript man of fifty crawls from the wreckage. Buzzcut. Shattered gasmask hanging from his face. A MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER. He's on his hands and knee bleeding from the mouth, from a gash in his hairline. Russell puts a gun to his head.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Welcome to Marsh County. Friendliest Place on Earth. David runs up. Judy behind.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Russ! Russ! Let me talk to him!  77. Russell mulls it over, gun on the guy’s head. Backs off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Intelligence Officer) What did you people spill? The Intelligence Officer spits blood, looks up at David, dazed, angry.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The guy standing between you and a bullet. The Intelligence Officer spits more blood then shifts painfully into a seated position. Pulls off the shattered gasmask. Tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What were we exposed to? After a moment, with a sigh of resignation:

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Zoonotic agent, rhabdoviridea prototype.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Rhabdoviridea... You mean, rabies?

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: With a few alterations and enhancements.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What’s he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (shocked; sickened) A weapon. A biological weapon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa, wait a minute, you guys engineered this crap?! You got any idea what it does to people?!

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: It does what it was designed to do. Destabilize a population. In this case, the wrong one. (off their stunned looks) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER (cont'd) We lost a plane, fellas, what do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How about ‘sorry for destroying your whole goddamn town’?!

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Take it up with the pilot, I came down here to help! David has no answer for that. The Intelligence Officer, l Billy Babcock, defies the ‘enemy’ label, just another guy a different side of the issue doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What’s the incubation period?

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours. After that, you're either dead or you don’t have it. But they’re afraid it could go airborne. It’s rare but it happens and they’re not taking any chances.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: How rare?

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: One-in-a-million.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You guys are gonna let us die here for one-in-a-million odds?

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: When the risk is global pandemic? You're goddamn right. One carrier is all it takes. Nobody leaves. Grim silence. The Intelligence Officer struggles to his feet, leans wobbly-legged against the wreckage, somebody' husband, somebody's father, the beaten hero of his own st

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (apologetic) For what it’s worth, I -- BANG! - his head jerks back as a bullet rips through his forehead. Russell just shot him from behind David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nooo!!!  79. Judy is SCREAMING. Falls down as she staggers backwards. Has never seen someone shot at close range. David grabs Russell two-fisted by the shirt and walks him backwards i the field, yelling in his face.

dialogues.speaker: WANTED TO TALK TO HIM
dialogues.text: Russell holds David's stare, coldly indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You talked. Russell shoulders his rifle and walks off, picking up a portable MILITARY RADIO from the debris along the way. Da watches him then helps Judy to her feet. A DEAD INTELLIGENCE OFFICER IN A KANSAS CORNFIELD. Blood, sprayed across the Suburban's undercarriage, SIZZLING on hot exhaust pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy walk the sun-scorched highway, eyes traine Russell who walks fifty paces in front, a man to fear.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I‘ll get the guns from him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What if he tries to stop you? Russell, out of earshot, glances back at them as if knowi their private thoughts. Turns forward again. And we get David's reply:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He's a good kid, but I'll kill him if I have to. Russell starts to jog. David and Judy match his stride, maintaining that fifty-pace separation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abandoned filling station. Russell crosses the lot and go inside. David and Judy arrive moments later and follow hi Tense. Moment of truth.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy enter. On the far wall is a cooler filled with BOTTLED WATER. Russell tosses them both a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thanks. Russell exits without a word. Steps outside and pours an entire bottle over his head. Opens a second bottle and si down drinking it on the concrete median by the pumps. David and Judy guzzle, the excess water running down thei necks. Both watching Russell through the window as he SCA THE CHANNELS on the military radio. STATIC. He puts the radio down and heads for the men’s room. David sees Russell’s mistake. The radio, and HIS GUNS, sitting by the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, at the urinal, flushes, zips, steps to the sink where he blows his nose into his handkerchief. THE WHITE CLOTH TURNS DARK RED, FILLING WITH BLOOD. He tucks it away, seemingly unaware. Stares at himself in the cracked mirror. Dead-eyed. Sweat rivering down his cheeks. Madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell exits. Sees his guns are gone. Flushing with rage he crosses to David, who has them.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I'm gonna need those back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'll carry 'em for a while. You've been carrying 'em the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks anyway. Russell reaches for them. David shakes his head, stony.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I got ‘em.  81.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. Russell nods, nods again, then draws from behind his back SPARE HANDGUN. David is hopelessly outdrawn. Judy white with terror.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Russell, we're on your side...

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: My side? I didn't even know there was sides.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: There's not, I didn't --

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Tell her to shut up. David gestures. Judy stops talking. Russell presses the g to David's chest.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Judy while looking at Russell) Stop talking. Let him think about what he's doing. Russell stares David in the face. Finger on the trigger. Taps him bluntly on the chest with the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: One.. (taps him again) Two... (taps him again) Three! You're waiting for the gunshot but Russell just shakes hi head in reproach.  82.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: That's how many times I saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, who now has all the guns, gestures down the road with his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (e.g. ‘walk’) Out in front where I can see you. David and Judy start down the road, Russell behind them. They talk under their breath.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Let's just run.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. Give him a target he'll hit it. Let me think a minute. They walk on, weighing their options. And David realizes. They have none.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (turns) Fuck it, I'm gonna confront him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: David, no -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We don't get to that truck stop we're dead anyway. He walks back toward Russell. Russell raises the M-16.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Back off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OFF
dialogues.text: Russell takes aim at David's face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just wanna talk.  83.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Put the gun down. Russell tightens on the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You better listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Put it down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just want to talk to you. David walks right up to him. The M-16 pointed at his thro Russell staring down the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Can we talk? Man to man? A long tense moment then Russell lowers his weapon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. Here's the deal -- David PUNCHES HIM square in the face, lays him out flat. Russell, dazed, offers no resistance as David quietly dis him, just stares at the sky like he's daydreaming:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (hazy) Remember that monster catfish I caught last summer?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (disarming him) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (hazy) What'd he weigh, you reckon?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (disarming him) Ten fifteen pounds.  84. Faint smile from Russell.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (hazy) Big son of a bitch. Judy arrives, her shadow falling across Russell who sits now, semi-lucid, the suckerpunch helping clear his head.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I'm not right, am I? David shakes his head no. Russell nods in confirmation. Unexpectedly, his voice cracks with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Can I keep walking with you guys? Little while longer? David trades looks with Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're jogging again. Russell struggling to keep up. Jud drinks from a water bottle, passes it to David. He finish it, tosses it. And before the bottle hits the ground - he grabs her and pull her into the tall grass. They peer through it. Both crouching. TWO MILITARY TRUCKS butted together form a CHECKPOINT two hundred yards down the road. SIX HEAVILY ARMED SOLDIERS I BIOSUITS. No way past. Russell arrives beside them, huffing. Sizes up the checkpoint. Indicates a route through the adjoining field

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Cut through there, you can pick up the highway on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They'll see us.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: They'll be focusin' on me. David looks at Russell. He's offering to sacrifice himsel

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Deputy does what the sheriff tells him. You're the sheriff. Permission. David can't give it. Russell holds out his ha for a gun.  85.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I’m done, chief, let me go out big. Moment of deliberation then David puts the revolver in Russell’s hand, making sure it's fully loaded. A beat and then he gives him the shotgun as well, pumping his last shells into the chamber. Gun in each hand, Russell eyes t checkpoint. Steeling himself. Looks at David one last tim

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hoo-fuckin'-yah. And takes off through the field toward the checkpoint. We run with him, immersed in the sounds - the SWISHING GRASS his POUNDING STEPS, and the ROCK ANTHEM he's singing unde his breath to psych himself up ("Walk This Way"):

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Met a cheerleader was a real young bleeder oh the times I could reminisce, 'Cause the best things of lovin' with her sister and her cousin only started with a little kiss, like this... He OPENS FIRE, veering out of the field in a dead sprint the checkpoint. Takes out four of the six soldiers before they gun him down. The remaining soldiers gather around Russell's body. Davi and Judy running to safety through the opposite field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A road sign. Quik Phil's Truckstop 1/2 MILE. David and Ju lengthen their strides.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on. We're there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy slow as they reach the parking lot, anticipation turning to dread. THE TRUCKSTOP IS ABANDONED. A ghost town. They kick aside the temporary fencing and w across the empty parking lot. It's strewn with litter lik state fairground at the end of the season.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It was Grand Central last night.  86.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: They must have gotten everybody out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In what...? The EVACUATION BUSES are parked in the same spot as befor And booted, like the cars in town, to prevent driving. It eerily quiet. Which makes the one sound they do hear all more ominous. A STEADY HUM from the far side of the parking lot where T REFRIGERATED BIG RIG TRAILERS ARE LINED UP. David and Judy exchange a grim look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-footers. Back doors padlocked. Refrigeration unit HUMMING. David breaks open a padlock using the shotgun as pry arm. Swings open the door...

dialogues.speaker: THEIR WRISTS.
dialogues.text: David and Judy stare in disbelief. We never see inside th trailer itself. Their faces tell the story.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: They weren't even sick... David picks something up off the ground. A HANDFUL OF M-16 SHELL CASINGS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nobody leaves. He flings them across the parking lot in disgust. We hear the shells CLINKING and PINGING over an image of the dang dead arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trash can SHATTERS the glass door. David and Judy step through and survey the deserted truckstop. Slot machines glimmer multi-colored in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy lean over a KANSAS MAP in the empty restaurant. The soft HISS of static on the military radio  87.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We don't get outta here nobody's ever gonna know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: They wiped out an entire town. What are they going to say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whatever they want. (indicates map) All these roads are gonna be blocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grab supplies. Bottled water. Chocolate bars. Hats and sunglasses from a display rack as they exit. INT. CORRIDOR, QUICK PHIL’S TRUCKSTOP - CONTINUOUS Come down the hall toward the main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thirty miles to Wichita. On foot, avoiding main roads, we’ll average maybe three four miles an hour. That gets us there by daybreak. A NOISE stops them. Came from just around the corner. The is it again. The sound of a COIN TUMBLING THROUGH A PAY PHONE, being t from the return slot and reinserted at the top where it tumbles down again and again and again. David motions for Judy to remain silent and perfectly sti Tiptoes to the corner. Peers around it. Sitting in one of those private pay phone stalls with his back to us is a beast of a man, a giant Oklahoma TRUCK DR in a blood-stained tanktop. The blood is his own, seeping from a gunshot he took in the chest and didn’t die from. David ducks back around the corner. Holy shit. He turns back to Judy, motioning for her to head back the opposite direction. But just then we hear -

dialogues.speaker: OF IT ROLLING EVER NEARER...
dialogues.text: It rolls into view and goes into one of those lazy spins front of David and Judy.  88. A stunned pause then they start backing away. Quickly and quietly as possible. The COIN spinning faster and faster. The truck driver's FOOTSTEPS approaching. He comes around the corner, looks up from the coin at Dav and Judy. His face is grotesque:

dialogues.speaker: JERKING BACK TO EXPOSE THE TEETH AND GUMS.
dialogues.text: As he stands there staring at them - BANG! - he takes a bullet in the side of the head. Gore sprays from the exit wound. He falls and we hear DELIRIOUS HOWLS down the hall In one of those corner-mounted security mirrors, David an Judy see who fired the shot -

dialogues.speaker: THE REDNECK HUNTERS
dialogues.text: Trudging down the hall in their blood-soaked orange vests David gestures for Judy to back up fast. She does and he follows her, the two of them retreating into the INT. RESTAURANT, QUIK PHIL’S - NIGHT Immediately they are forced to hit the floor as -

dialogues.speaker: THE PICKUP TRUCK
dialogues.text: driven by the THIRD HUNTER, pulls up right outside the windows, the back of it heaped with bodies. David and Jud flat on their stomachs, draw quick terrified breaths.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Did he see us?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know. We gotta move. They crawl across the carpet toward the far side of the restaurant. The two hunters drag the dead truckdriver out by his ankl and heave his body up onto the pile. The third hunter LAY ON THE HORN in celebration of the kill. David and Judy crawl behind the counter, through a swingi door into the - INT. KITCHEN, QUIK PHIL’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT They pause just inside, breathless with fear. David, steadying the swinging door with his fingertips, trying t think what to do next.  89.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Maybe they’1l leave. David gives her a doubtful look, steals a peek through th window in the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Truck’s still there. The driver's seat is empty. No sign of the hunters anywhe Until -

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE OF THEM ENTER THE RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: guffawing, guns leveled, looking for prey.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fuck. David ducks down. Scans the kitchen. No visible exits. They’re trapped.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where are they? David gestures ‘right there, shhhhh.’ He peers through th crack in the door, watching as: The hunters search the restaurant, looking under tables, working their way through the seating area toward the kitchen. One of them slips out of view as they approach.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They're coming. David and Judy retreat toward the back of the kitchen. Da grabs a couple of knives as they pass the cook’s station, hands one to Judy. They hide around a corner, flatten themselves against the wall, David with a finger to his l telling Judy not to make a sound. And now -

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN DOORS
dialogues.text: swing open. The two hunters enter. We hear their heavy bootsteps. The treads leaving bloody footprints on the tiles. They make their way past the cook’s station and th sink to

dialogues.speaker: THE VERY CORNER WHERE DAVID AND JUDY ARE HIDING
dialogues.text: Here they pause, as if sensing their prey, and then, together, whip around the corner, guns up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where? We find them around the next corner, their fin fallback position. They listen, clutching the knives, to ADVANCING FOOTSTEPS of the hunters. In the final seconds David sees -

dialogues.speaker: A DOOR
dialogues.text: ten feet away. Fire exit. Can they make it? He motions to Judy. They go for it. Slip through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop dead in their tracks on the other side. Standing rig in front of them is

dialogues.speaker: THE THIRD HUNTER
dialogues.text: With an excited grunt he puts the gun in David’s face and pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: CLICK
dialogues.text: Idiot forgot to reload. David drives the knife into his n and leaves it there as he and Judy take off down the hall The hunter drops to his knees, puking up handfuls of bloo The other two hunters explode through the door and open f David and Judy run for their lives. The hunters in hot pursuit, galloping along in their bloody boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy cut through an arcade. Pinball machines an slot machines flying past in a blur. BOOM! - a shotgun bl vaporizes a Pacman machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the arcade into a hallway with one flickering fluorescent light. David grabs door handles as they run, looking for an exit. This one opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. They run on. Desperate. GUNSHOTS chasing them aroun the corners. The hunters closing in. Nowhere to run. Except this -—

dialogues.speaker: LAST DOOR
dialogues.text: David yanks it open. He and Judy race through, down a

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: gl. lined with vending machines and chairs that widens into a lobby of some sort.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DOOR
dialogues.text: Flies open. David and Judy, charging through, find themselves in -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavernous work area where they service the rigs. Davi locks the door behind them. A temporary respite because a

dialogues.speaker: PLATE GLASS WINDOW
dialogues.text: looks in from the lobby. As soon as they see it, the two hunters are there. David spins, sees:

dialogues.speaker: LIFT.
dialogues.text: On the wall nearby are a DOZEN SETS OF KEYS. David lunges grabs them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Climb! Scaling tool chests and oil drums, David and Judy climb u the elevated truck cab as -

dialogues.speaker: THE HUNTERS SHATTER THE WINDOW AND CLIMB INSIDE THE GARAG
dialogues.text: David and Judy dive inside the cab as shotgun blasts pulverize the doors. The hunters keep shooting, emptying their guns at the elevated rig. When they stop to reload

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy, crouched on the floor, seize the moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Lock ‘em! They both lock their doors and crouch back down, bracing themselves for another assault. But there are no more gunshots. Not yet. What they hear instead are TOOLS SPILLING TO THE FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, they’re climbing up! David jumps into the driver’s seat as the FIRST HUNTER CL INTO VIEW. He meets David's gaze with a murderous grin. Aims his shotgun at the glass.  92. David kicks his door open, sending the hunter flying off the floor below where his SKULL HITS with a SICKENING CRA Undeterred, he starts climbing back up. The SECOND HUNTER scaling the tool chests ahead of him. But David sees something far more terrifying than these t

dialogues.speaker: THE THIRD HUNTER
dialogues.text: climbs in through the lobby window. Knife still embedded his neck, blood rivering from the wound, he glares up at David in the truck then starts looking around for somethi Sees it over there on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE HYDRAULIC RELEASE BUTTON
dialogues.text: David reads his intention, tosses Judy the keys. No time waste.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: See if any of those work! Judy starts trying them in the ignition, one after anothe tossing the useless sets aside. The Third Hunter could just press the release button, but decides to shoot it instead. Blows the entire switch assembly off the wall. THE RIG DOESN’T MOVE. So the Third Hunter walks over under the truck and starts firing randomly into the sub-floor mechanics of the lift itself. He finally hits some vital part, not anticipating the outcome -— WITH A HYDRAULIC WHOOSH THE BIG RIG DROPS STRAIGHT DOWN. Judy SCREAMING in freefall. WHAM! - THE RIG LANDS, CRUSHING the THIRD HUNTER UNDERNEA The other two hunters find this mishap hilarious, LAUGH UPROARIOUSLY. A strange interlude. Judy desperately fishi around on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I dropped the keys! David bends to help. Something hits the windshield like a sledgehammer.  93.

dialogues.speaker: WINDSHIELD WITH A TEN POUND STEEL WRENCH.
dialogues.text: Devastating blows. Each impact WHITENS THE GLASS, sending pebbled fragments flying back at David’s and Judy's faces Judy trying whatever keys she can find.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: None of them work! WHAM! More pebbled fragments flying back at them. Judy, ducking it, fishes around on the floor for more keys. Fin another set. Tries them. No good.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I can't find them! Fishes around under the seat. Finds another set. Jams the in the ignition and

dialogues.speaker: LIFE.
dialogues.text: David lets out a howl.

dialogues.speaker: YEEEAH
dialogues.text: Throws the rig into gear and with the AIRHORN BLARING -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMES CRASHING OUT through the garage door. The rig tears off across the parking lot with the redneck hunters staggering after it on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speeding down the highway. Pulses pounding. Judy unfolds map from the glovebox.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: The smallest straightest road to Wichita.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Perfect.  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck races down a country lane, a big moonlit dust c rising in its wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy fiddles with the MILITARY RADIO, picks up a STATICKY SIGNAL.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What was that? She fiddles some more. Snippets of MILITARY COMMUNICATION becoming audible through the STATIC:

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...Fifty-nine... (STATIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fifty-five...fifty-four... (STATIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fifty-one...fifty... Judy and David turn slowly to look at one another. Haunte by the same question.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What happens at zero? David floors the gas pedal.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...forty-five...forty-four... (STATIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...forty-two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck barrels toward us down the quiet country road.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-thirty-six...thirty-five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy race on, rigid with fear. The dark countryside shooting past the windows.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ..-thirty...twenty-nine...twenty- eight... Judy scrambles into the sleeper compartment, watching out back window.  95.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...twenty...nineteen...eighteen... seventeen...sixteen... JUDY'S POV - The road receding toward the black horizon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (pedal to floor) That's everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WILD WHITE EYES of frightened horses jumping back fro roadside fence as the truck flies past.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...twelve...eleven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's white-knuckled grip on the wheel. Judy's face pressed against the back window. That ominous STATIC-LACE VOICE on the radio:

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...ten...nine...eight... The road flying toward us out of darkness.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...five... David's face.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ..-four... Judy’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...three... Judy reaching over, gripping David's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: «+.two... David gripping her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COM
dialogues.text: ...one...  96. Zero. Judy staring out. David craning his neck.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Anything? Judy silent, waiting, staring.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Anything?!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nothing? Just the black horizon. Judy, baffled, meets eyes with Da in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Nothing. And then it hits.

dialogues.speaker: HOLE IN THE NIGHT SKY.
dialogues.text: Searing white light fills the cab. Judy watching the blas through her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT
dialogues.text: David, bone-chilled, looks out his side window, sees —

dialogues.speaker: A LUMINOUS SHOCKWAVE RACING ACROSS THE PRAIRIE BEHIND THE
dialogues.text: sweeping over eerily backlit barns and houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shockwave wallops the truck like a punch from God, pitching it forward on the front axle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield we see the shockwave go shooting p us down the highway, Mach One, its vacuum sucking out the rig's side windows - BOOSH!  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck falls back onto its rear wheels, SNAPPING THE R AXLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David wrestles the rig under control, steers it onto the shoulder, the axle GRINDING ON PAVEMENT. The initial blinding burst dims to an EERIE CRIMSON HALFLIGHT and we the aftermath, a NETHERWORLD of fire and smoke and swirli ashes: A mile-wide CORNFIELD engulfed in flames. The POSTS OF A WOODEN FENCE like a row of torches. A hellish BLACK-ORANG MUSHROOM CLOUD rising up from the prairie beyond. David and Judy stare in speechless horror. STATIC crackli on the military radio like the countdown never happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Judy trudge through waist-high grass. Sun pinkening the sky in the east. Wichita on the near horizo Looks of hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People. Traffic. Life as normal. David and Judy walk up a commercial street in the trucker hats and sunglasses they took from Quik Phil’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greasy spoon. Full of PATRONS. David sits at the counter his trucker hat and sunglasses. Quiet. Inconspicuous. Jud is on the pay phone in the back. She hangs up, comes over and sits on the stool beside David.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: My parents are coming to get us. David holds his reply as the waitress steps up, pen poise take their order.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: What'1ll it be?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Couple waters.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: That it?  98. He nods, catches her hand as she turns.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bottled. She nods okay. On a tv above the counter, regular programming is interrupted by a SPECIAL NEWS UPDATE. Patr look up from their meals with the concern one feels for a neighboring community.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS UPDATE
dialogues.text: Casualties continue to mount following a devastating explosion at a chemical plant in rural Kansas. Ogden Marsh, a farming community of some four hundred families, is believed to have been leveled in the blast. Authorities continue to search for survivors, but hold out little hope. More as this tragic story unfolds... The official version of events. David watches in disgust. Judy in disbelief, stating the obvious:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That’s not what happened. The waitress brings the waters and the check. As David reaches for the bottles, he pauses, noticing something. There, on the check, by the waitress's smiley-face signature...

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK SPOT
dialogues.text: Strange. Like ink from a broken pen. He lifts his sunglasses and the spot turns it's natural color:

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Disbelief. He touches his fingers to his nose. They come back dripping. Judy sees the blood. Her look of horror is our final image.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No... FADE OUT.
